		<shortDescription>Loved it--but only in comparison to Russian Version.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I LOVED this movie, but after a bit of reflection I think that most of what I liked about it relate directly to how it does or does not deviate from the Tarkovsky version. I'm not sure how much I would have cared if I had seen it on its own. MANY people walked out of the opening night screening I was at. Today a Fox exec in the NYTimes says he guesses "it wasn't the Holiday Fare we thought it would be." Well, Fox Exec, maybe a brain would be in order. It's too bad this film will be seen as a flop because they're putting it out in a season and with a campaign guarateeing it to tank. Nice move, Fox. The performances all round were good. The acting here is extra challenging because they have to act realistically in a totally bizarre and false situation, and I think they all do well. In this way it reminded me of "Existenz"--having to act naturally in a surreal situation. At first I was thinking "I am being prevented from examining the serious moral and philosophical issues presented here because George Clooney is just SO DAMN HANDSOME!" but I think it's a testament to his acting that it is possible to forget that after a while. The real revelation was Natasha McE, who I think had to show some of the most raw emotions in situations that don't call for it, and she really ran off with the gold. The script--and this may come as a surprise to those who say this is the most boring thing they had ever seen--was clearly written to emphasize the THRILLER aspect of the story. If you've seen the 3-hour Russian version (which I wrote a scathing review about on IMDb, but has grown in my estimation since) you can spend the first half-hour admiring the economy with which the story is told. I also loved the care and composition of every shot in the first two-thirds. The conception of the planet was very good, very beautiful, but, like much of the film, I think it got away from Soderbergh in the end. No one ever comes out and SAYS "the planet is a sentient being," and I think it would have helped the movie if they had, because just changing the color of the planet as the film moves along and interspersing shots of it with George thinking does NOT necessarily make the connection, and toward the end it began to feel like "Hmm, I don't know what to do here... okay, let's just show the planet again!" This film erred on the side of subtlety too often I thought, which may be admirable in some situations, but here I think it actually held the film back, because if you HAD the information, you could proceed to think about what was happening and what it meant, rather than just trying to catch up with what was happening at all. Some things I think should have been SAID OUTRIGHT: (SPOILERS here:) "The planet is a sentient being!" "But your wife is dead!" "My wife was unfaithful!" "My wife killed herself!" and "The space station is sinking INTO the planet!"(SPOILERS END) I really enjoyed the music. It was very reminiscent of Philip Glass (and I can't help thinking would have been better if it WERE by Philip Glass, not that I don't love ya, Cliff, and that opening music to "Kafka" is ASTOUNDING). I also loved the long musical passages of the film, I wish more films would do this--though of course then it would turn to crap. Unfortunately, I feel like Soderbergh lost control of the film at the end. I was quite surprised at the beginning that he had jettisoned Kelvin's father and the rest of his family, a decision that I think comes back to haunt the ending, and really strip it of the emotional heft the earlier version had. This version, limiting the focus only to the love of the wife, and moving away from her place within the larger scope of his family and his entire existence, I think made the film a bit banal in the end. Okay, let's face it, the whole concept of this movie is straight outta original series Star Trek, but for the way it's handled, but compared to the Tarkovsky, it just seems less weighty. This movie begins to lose focus in the final third, and even the shots themselves do not seem as controlled. I was stunned that he also dropped the final shot of the Tarkovsky version, which almost single-handedly explained what you just saw, and I just don't think that what he came up with compared in any way. The placement of the flashbacks also just started to feel arbitrary, and the one crucial one RIGHT at the end I really think should have been inserted much before, it has the effect of stopping the momentum. Nevertheless, I can't wait to see it again. I think I might rent the Tarkovsky version (and watch it with the benefit of a fast-forward button) then see this once more. I also think, if you're going to see it, DON'T rent it, but definitely see it in all its beauty on the big screen, and when your attention will be focused on the screen.Regardless of the minor flaws, big props to Steven and George for doing this. I wish this film would always be at theaters so I could go see it whenever I want.--- Check out website devoted to bad and cheesy movies: www.cinemademerde.com</fullReview>

The directing was decent, the acting was at times very good, and even most of the dialogue was fairly intelligent, but the story, the true substance of the movie, was trite, muddled, and downright poor. At least Kubrick had a point to his great piece. Soderbergh, on the other hand, is attempting to be deep without having anything really to say. The premise reminded me of a guilty pleasure of mine, Event Horizon, though in Solaris, there is absolutely no follow through. I have never felt so detached from the characters in a movie in my life. Jeremy Davies provoked an occasional smirk, but other than that, I felt absolutely nothing throughout the entirety of the movie, until feeling very very upset as I exited the theater. Davies' mildly humorous performance upgraded this picture from a $10 root canal to a botched filling. Take my advice: for true sci-fi mastery, see 2001. For a fun and creepy b sci-fi flick, check out Event Horizon. Steve, you simply should not attempt what has already been done. Just because you left the fetus out of the sphere at the conclusion of the film, it doesn't mean I, as well as many others I'm sure, didn't see what you were doing, and as a Kubrick defender, I am insulted by your "movie". 		<username>pigsflew3000</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>The film equivalent of a Sharper Image catalog.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I really wanted to like this movie. However, it came off like a Sharper Image catalog: glossy, slick, and full of a lot of cool stuff. On the other hand, I would never really buy anything out of a Sharper Image catalog. The visuals and sets are no less than stunning. The story - with its elements of love, loss, memories, and atonement - is a good one, though its execution suffers with some inconsistent points. Where Solaris falls flat is in its pacing and its acting. The movie presents itself as a thriller/experimental/sci-fi/romance/etc, but the pace never goes above a crawl. This sort of slow and atmospheric pacing works very well when done with style (Pi, for example, with its brooding intensity). In Solaris, it is mildly boring. The acting is cold and mechanical. Perhaps this is a statement on life in this future, perhaps not. In any case, it is very difficult to feel sympathy for any of the characters, as none of them are memorable enough to really get engaged in their lives or situations. Another very strange element to this film is its soundtrack. In the trailers, a sweeping and very cinematic score accompanies the actions onscreen. In the actual movie, the ambience is provided by an incessant steel drum and bell chorus. The same phrase plays throughout the entire movie. For the first hour or so, it emphasizes the isolation and repetition of a desperate situation; in the latter portion of the movie it becomes annoying. Cinematic scores are very stirring to provide emotional cues - they tell you exactly how to interpret the story. When done poorly, they seem intrusive. When done well, they subtly guide you along. If not done at all, it is a very rare movie that feels complete. Solaris is a bit difficult to review. After leaving the theater, I initially enjoyed it quite a bit. The more I thought about it, the less I liked it. See Solaris on the big screen only if you have the patience to invest time and thought in a cold and inaccessible film with some interesting ideas and great visuals. Otherwise, save it for a rental.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Solaris: Ponderous, man</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Why is Hollywood so afraid of exploring intelligent science fiction (ala 2001, Alien, , Blade Runner, Matrix)? Why is Solaris a ponderous,plodding, tale of obsession? I know it's based on a novel, and a 70s movie, neither of which I'm familiar with. I just can't comprehend why anyone would remake this material in this fashion.Don't get me wrong, Solaris is beautifully filmed; Soderbergh has obviously seen 2001 a few times. It's just that the illogical turns, and unexplored possibilities, submarine the whole thing.For example, why does Clooney's friend invite him to Solaris, saying he's the "perfect" person to be there? The illogic of this has to be intentional, but why? Upon arrival, Clooney turns from a top-notch psychiatrist into an irrational fool. No interest into getting to the bottom of what's going on, just indulgence of his own subconscious. And of course, no contact with Earth to keep him rooted in his mission. The ending is too muddled and contrived to spawn any post-movie discussions.Yeah, I know, its intended to be a psychological piece, and it has all the trappings of an "important" movie. But it's a failed attempt to be something more than what it is... ponderous eye-candy.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-11-27</date>
		<username>allan825</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>miss...miss...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tarkovsky's adaptation of Lem's novel takes quite a few liberties, jettisoning, for instance, the brilliant satirical elements and re-creating in its own potent terms the story's fascinating strangeness. But Tarkovsky does remain true to the novel's central sci-fi premise: that life elsewhere in the universe may have evolved along lines so different from life on Earth that we could never fathom it. Lem's novel, then, is an extraordinary rebuttal of all the ridiculous, anthropomorphic sci-fi scenarios in which aliens appear as strangely familiar humanoids (often demanding to be taken to some leader, in English). The new Solaris strats from the original in a far more fundamental way than Tarkovsky did, shifting the focus from the mind-bending sci-fi premise to something far more predictable and far less interesting: a rather conventional tale (told largely through flashbacks) of love, regret, and redemption. Instead of Lem's world-wide sentient ocean, we get a few shots of some neon clouds--and virtually no explanation at all of what Solaris is. In fact, Solaris itself becomes so peripheral to the story that one almost wonders why the filmmakers even bothered to use the name. The film will probably come as a major disappointment to fans of the original (or of the earlier film version, with its unique `Tarkovskyan' style and atmosphere). It will also disappoint the casual cineplex viewer who expects that since Cameron's name is linked with the project that it must be some rip-roaring rollercoaster ride rather along the lines of another Aliens or Terminator II. (Thus "miss...miss...") Yes, the film's quite slow, but the slowness is not enigmatic and compelling as in Tarkovsky; it's mostly boring and often unimaginative. And the performances certainly do not redeem the picture. One in particular (the `dude' who plays Snow) is almost fascinating in its sheer badness. The difference between Lem (and Tarkovsky) and the new version is nowhere more apparent (or disappointing) than in the ending. In place of the fathomless ambiguities of the novel's conclusion (`I persisted in the faith that the time of cruel miracles was not past'), we get a rather saccharine, allegorical happy ending. `Cruel miracles': no, there's nothing remotely to compare with that. The shift toward allegory is strongly reinforced by an iconic (and rather pedestrian) visual allusion to Michelangelo. At the same time, I suppose, one could see the scene as an allusion to Kubrick's `Star-Child'. Throughout, the film's visual style and sudden fits of Ligeti-like music owe much more to 2001 than to anything in Tarkovsky--and to say that the invited comparison is not in the newer film's favor is a bit of an understatement. The filmmakers seem to depend on the beautiful stars to carry the viewer's interest, in lieu of the braintwisting thematic substance of the original(s). Yes, I enjoyed watching Natascha McElhone's high-cheekboned face--in fact the main reason I stayed to the end was to find out the actress's name (since there are no opening credits). But that's candy rather than nutrition. I strongly recommend--especially to those who have yet to encounter Lem or Tarkovsky--that you stay home and either read the novel or rent the earlier version. Having done both a couple of times, I still wished I had made that choice.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2014-08-26</date>
		<username>alexandresobreira-12-509311</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Terrible view of a good book</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't know why people compare Tarkowsky's Solaris to 2001. Sure, that's what Tarkowsky intended. But while 2001 is the best sci-fi movie of all time, Solaris not even sci-fi. It distorts Stanislaw Lem's view of the universe and actually changes it around. Of course, many people think it's a work of genius by the way it throws philosophy around, but that's for those who like philosophy. I think philosophy is silly and overblown all around. Science (the daughter of Greek thinking - which I don't really consider philosophy in the modern, especially German, sense, but as a way to try to understand the universe) is the only form of thinking that's valid. So, I think that, although entertaining, both the 1972 Solaris and the book are rather silly in their opposite ways of considering the impossibility of humanity ever understanding the universe (which is obviously false by all accounts). That said, both are a zillion times better than this movie. Of course the decision of focusing on Kelvin's love life robs the film of all depth, but it goes beyond that. In trying to "modernize" the story by having Nasa selling the Solaris project to some corporation, you get the old and trite left-wing Hollywood trope of evil Capitalism trying to exploit nature as represented by Solaris. You don't get the actual core of the novel, which is the futile attempt of Solaristics to understand Solaris - and by extension the universe as a whole - but rather, as one of the Company (what a rip-off from Alien) agents say, "the possibility of exploiting Solaris economically". And the casting if abominable. Corey Feldman is, of course, the most ridiculous of them all, with his crazy gestures - and no, he doesn't use them here because his character is emotionally disturbed, he acts like that all the time, and I supposed he acts like that in real life too. But all the other actors are badly cast. Some have mentioned that Kelvin's wife - if forget her name now - is beautiful and renders a better performance that the others. But one of the key points of the book regarding her is her youth and innocence, in flagrant contrast to Kelvin, who is much older and cynical, which renders his shock at her return far more poignant. In that regard, Tarkowksy's casting is infinitely superior (also all the other points of this movie, silly as it is). In short, this is an awful movie. I tried to see it again today but found it almost unbearably embarrassing and boring. Stay away from it.</fullReview>

Certain camera shots (like seeing a character's face) feel unnecessarily long without adding substance, and at the same time, some story aspects are underdeveloped. There is no explanation for how clones of specific dead humans, with their memories, appear out of nowhere. The crew members are certain, by unknown reasons, that it's the planet below that creates them. Of course. And they are not unusually perplexed, amazed or in disbelief. It would have been potentially interesting to learn more about the planet Solaris.Also, more could have been done out of the main character's approach to Solaris. More emotion.At one point the characters discuss how the "visitors" are built. One of the crew members comes up with what is supposed to be a wild guess, the other one programs a particle accelerator (how come they have one on the ship to begin with?) based on that guess, and it just happens to be correct. And again, no questions asked and no explanations. There are multiple such ignored bits in this movie.The mentioned physics is bad too. Bosons do not have anti-particles, and the Higgs field gives *everything* mass, and exists everywhere. Although the Higgs was not yet experimentally confirmed by the time this movie was made, this has been theorised for some time. It would only take a simple internet search.However, the movie has some good aspects too. The visuals are beautiful. There is some really aesthetic lightning and scenery. The planet Solaris looks fascinating, and there are some nice shots of it. There are a few good story elements about love and regret, and the occasional emotional atmosphere. 		<shortDescription>Both beautiful and irritating...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Steven Soderbergh's remake of the 1972 Russian film "Solyaris" casts George Clooney as a psychologist who is sent a message by an old friend pleading the doctor to join himself and the crew of the space station Solaris for reasons undisclosed. Once aboard, Clooney discovers obvious distress and his friend's dead body--as well as a warning that what's happening on Solaris will soon happen to him. Good-looking picture with wonderful art direction, fluid pacing and precise editing in the dream sequences; however, the main character isn't very intriguing, and nearly all the performances are underwhelming. As a member of the paranoid surviving crew, twitchy Jeremy Davies is used as comic relief. Though the picture could certainly use some levity, Davies nearly sinks the movie with his low-key hipster ranting, annoying gum-chewing and distracting tics (also the fault of Soderbergh, who allows Davies too much screen-time to go into his pothead arias). I don't think Clooney is ever in character here; he seems overly conscious of the camera, working his handsomeness--his externals--tenderly as a way to connect with the audience. It doesn't substitute for a gripping characterization and, by the end, most viewers will feel indifferent to the romantic plot twist. ** from ****</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A rather dull film with some redeeming qualities</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Solaris has a runtime of roughly 90 minutes without logos and credits. Still, many of those precious minutes are spent on numerous stylized flashback sequences. Most of these definitely serve a purpose but take entirely too long and aren't particularly exciting to watch, being mostly dark and dim. Some of them feel arbitrary and purposefully stretched to boost the length of the film.It seems like Steven Soderbergh went out of his way to avoid exposition through dialogue, possibly out of fear of having it be too obvious or condescending. A lot of time is wasted on showing the audience that George Clooney is some kind of shrink. Yet, by the time he sets foot aboard the spaceship, we still have no idea what Solaris actually is or what kind of mission the crew is conducting. Simply knowing that might have greatly increased my enjoyment of the first half. The deliberate vagueness does not contribute to the sense of mystery at all, it just makes the characters less believable for not seeming all that bothered by it.Some credit is due for the way in which Soderbergh manages to portray the rather philosophical subject matter and have the characters explore and discuss it without breaking our suspension of disbelief. That being said, since none of this is technically original material, I think it's appropriate to base my rating mostly on artistic considerations. Intellect has little to do with one's enjoyment of this movie. It's definitely no Star Wars, but it's no 2001 either. It doesn't take a common man to get annoyed by the inconsistent pacing and dullness.</fullReview>

		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Slow, confusing and ambiguous like these sorts of films are but there is plenty here to keep you busy once the film has ended.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Science-fiction is one of those tough little genres that offers plenty to chew on in the form of content and ideas and yet you can have two extremely stark science fiction films; there are your Star Wars films and your films like Starship Troopers and Aliens that are able to tie in the war and romance genres, amongst others but then there are your more drawn out science fiction films such as 2001: A Space Odyssey which in themselves can be something spectacular whilst remaining ambiguous. Other films like Blade Runner and Alien can also use familiar narrative structures and yet are able to deliver on an entertaining and sophisticated level; at least to the masses, anyway.Solaris is a film made by Steven Soderbergh, a man who I am rapidly developing a split opinion of; Sex, Lies, &amp; Videotape was brilliant as was Ocean's Eleven albeit for different reasons; this twinned with Traffic which I thought was slightly overrated and Ocean's Twelve which was a mere exercise of cinematography and star power, if anything. Solaris is probably Soderbergh's most interesting film but that isn't saying it's his best in fact it's far from his best. Solaris actually emphasises 2001: A Space Odyssey's brilliance as a sci-fi film but also reinforces the fact that art can sometimes be entertaining as well as eerie ? Solaris may have been a bizarre and confusing film as 2001 was but it wasn't particularly eerie and at times at least to me, felt slow and dreary since I wasn't exactly sure as to what was going on.The film takes on a range of themes and attempts to reference previous sci-fi films from the past. The situation is straight out of Alien although the 'enemy' is a force that is not physical but psychological; Solaris also tries to use the idea of mental illness and psychological disturbance as its underlining theme since most of its character will suffer from hallucinations or seem to suffer from very random bouts of anger with pretty much the whole crew acting like they've got some horrible, dark secret locked away inside them. This actually moves me onto my next item: the hallucinations. It would seem that a massive ball of glowing energy is bringing back people from the crew's past lives and putting them on board with them in a sort of sick, Big Brother sort of a twist. This is where Solaris falters because Rheya (McElhone) and Chris (Clooney) begin to fall for one another yet again and the film quickly turns into a mere love story that's set in space with the bulk of these flash backs taking place on Earth; suddenly it's not so much a sci-fi as a character in a romance film having flashbacks.It's also worth noticing that within these flashbacks, there are numerous conversations between people and friends of Chris and Rheya about God and religion; this being significant since most of the flashbacks are these two peoples love stories. Flashing back to the present in space and Rheya herself says that she is 'unable to communicate with her creator' ? is this suggesting Solaris itself is indeed God? That this ball of energy can create life? because we are never sure if Rheya is a hallucination or indeed, a clone. This energy ball can clearly read minds and recreate organisms from raw memory right down to the colour of the person's eyes and their accent. This is where Solaris works because it's challenging the viewer to work out why certain people or things are there and what they're purpose is. The reference of the quote being that Rheya can't communicate with her creator since we can't communicate with God and the Solaris energy ball puts her in the same situation.It's worth saying that Solaris does not cover a lot of what it is. The purpose of the space ship, the reason the types of people that are on board were selected in the first place and why more people aren't sent remains unanswered. Also, the massive ball of energy is never really utilized as an element in the film: it is the reason there even is a film since it enables Chris to reconcile with Rheya both on Earth and in Space; remember that no one ever thinks to investigate Solaris further. I said it earlier but it still counts: Solaris is not a great film of sorts and only emphasises 2001: A Space Odyssey's brilliance since Solaris is a basic love story with a bizarre twist in the way it looks and feels. It's premise is interesting as a detective story but ends up as and consequently falters as a love story that's actually already happened down on Earth. Solaris is a film for people who will enjoy a good 'trip' but just like most sci-fi's, should never be a film you'll just 'pop in to give a watch'.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A decent remake for those without the patience for the original</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>With remakes, there's always going to be a comparison to the original. I think I would have liked this movie a little more if I had not already seen Tarkovsky's 1972 original. The first question with remakes I suppose should be why? I can see the reason for this film being to bring a really good sci-fi story to the younger generation that probably won't be seeing the 165min Russian original. I heard some comments that this movie was too slow or too boring. Well, in that case, I'm sure they wouldn't have had the patience for the original. I've also heard some sci-fi fans who really appreciate Soderbergh's version...in those cases, I'd consider the idea of doing the remake a success. I'm sure some of them would definitely appreciate the original, but I'm sure a certain percentage wouldn't be willing to sit through the same slow-paced story when the running time is nearly twice as long in the original. Soderbergh did a fine job with this movie and did fairly well at capturing the feeling of the original in a quicker time. If that was his vision, then I think he succeeded. He didn't really add anything new to this story. This movies is pretty much an exact, but compacted, copy of the original Tarkovsky film. The actors were adequate, but I didn't get the emotion, albeit subtle, that I got from the Russian original. I personally feel the gratuitous shots of Clooney's butt were unnecessary. In my opinion, Clooney's lead character may have been better with a lesser known actor. He plays the role fairly well and it's one of his more subtle performances to date, but you can't help but see certain Clooneyisms come out from time to time, especially when he gets upset. Though I feel Soderbergh did well to cast lesser knowns in the supporting roles. All in all, it's a decent remake bringing a solid sci-fi story to modern day fans of the genre, but I'd recommend the original to those who can make it through the epic length Russian version of this story.**1/2 (Out of 4)</fullReview>

Solaris is science fiction and this genre of film probably lends itself to the most preconceived ideas of what a movie should deliver so it's no wonder so many people were disappointed. Solaris would definitely get full points for set design, acting &amp; mystery but it is not an action movie nor is it an `effects' movie, although the effects that it did have were well done. I would classify Solaris as a 'thinking' movie. 		<date>2003-03-27</date>
		<username>phiggins</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Non-event Horizon. SPOILERS</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SPOILERS!! There was a guy. A doctor-guy whose wife was dead. He lived in the future. He was sent back to a planet called Solaris. He'd been there before, I think. Strange things were happening there. The guys who asked him to go back were out-of-focus, enigmatic, those kind of guys. In orbit around Solaris he found a woman locked in her room, a guy who was seriously wacky, and a kid. Some or all of these people should not have been there. It didn't take long for doctor-guy to start going as crazy as everyone else. Or did it? Or was he? Crazy, I mean. See, the doctor-guy's wife, dead as a door-nail, came back. To the space-ship. The one in orbit around Solaris. Our hero sent her away again, in a scene of painful simplicity: he got her into the module, locked her in, and she was gone, sliding out of the frame, a look of awful realisation on her face, staring at her husband, who had turned his back on her. But she came back again. See, the planet was doing this - creating apparently real manifestations of dead people. Why? To paraphrase Kinsgley Amis, the only sensible answer to this question is, "Yes, that's right, why?" The people on the spaceship (a downright strange brew of real and created people) sat down to see if they could sort things out. The scene that followed was weird and slightly laughable, one of two in which the film's grip began to falter (we'll get to the other one in a moment). They couldn't sort it out. But they could destroy the creations of Solaris using some contraption. This had been proved to work on a previous visitor. Our hero's "wife", fully aware that she was a fake, was quite keen on the idea. In fact, she begged for it to happen. It did happen. Then it turned out that one of the people we thought was real was fake too. Our hero was pretty well gone by this point, as were most of the audience - a Hollywood movie set in the future and there's no lasers or chases or fights or gadgets? How very strange. Our hero first met the woman who was to become his wife at a party. They exchanged glances, they flirted ("Don't blow it") they quoted poetry. On paper it all sounds pretty awful. On film, as realised by that master of popular cinema, Mister S. Soderbergh, it is magnificent. The camerawork, the lighting, the editing, the sound, the performances, all combine in the earth-bound flashback scenes to paint a languid, seductive picture of two people falling in love. The only things I can compare these scenes to are, perhaps not that surprisingly, the two earlier Clooney/Soderbergh classics, "Out of Sight" and "Ocean's Eleven". All three films contain sterling work by Clooney, oozing charm and creating a fizzing chemistry with his leading ladies. Meanwhile, back in the future, back in space, our hero has to make a decision. Should he stay or should he go? Back in his apartment on earth he is chopping vegetables. He cuts his finger. The cut disappears. His wife is there. They embrace. And this is the other moment in which the film falters for a second, almost loses it, and us. The doctor-guy stands there, in a faintly ridiculous pose, his arms slightly outstretched, his face expressing a weary surprise. It looks odd and, again, slightly laughable. The film recovers, just about, and fades to black, and to the titles. The end. Discuss.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Graham Rowe</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Could have been so much better... (Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It takes a brave man to follow Tarkovsky's answer to 2001 and Steven Soderbergh is that at least. First, the good: the film looks beautiful and the score lulls you into a relaxed, observatory state of mind. The cast are attractive and the worst of the anachronisms of Lem's book have been removed. There is actually a resolution to the movie and it is far more emotionally literate than either of the originals. Saying that there is much that has been messed about with to very little effect other than to ruin the intended plot. The essence of Solaris (the book) is an exploration into Man's (I do not mean to imply gender here) method of scientific analysis and how fallible that approach would be for an intelligence that exceeded their own. The only meaningful dialogue with the vast sentience that is Solaris comes from Kelvin's unresolved regret for the loss of Rheya, his love for her and the transmission of his unconscious thoughts to the planet itself. In this adaptation (mega-spoilers here): - Solaris itself appears never to have been studied or visited and the whole idea of the 'living sea' is lost.- 'Coroporations' (very 21st century and totally irrelevant to the plot) want to own Solaris as 'a possible energy source'. Again, why? This is both impossible (Steven do you understand *anything* about physics?) and detracts from one of the central points about the book which is Man's pure academic struggle to understand an intelligence greater than their own. The entire space station's library in the original(s) were devoted to decades of study into the phenomenon of Solaris. In the mythology of the book the planet has formed whole schools of thought and analysis - all lost here- Berton is lost from the plot and his son becomes Gibarian's. This character then becomes the representative of the planet. Neither the book or the Tarkovsky version needed this device so why do we in this film?- Snow (Snaut) has become an alien. Why? It was not necessary to the plot. The planet never knowingly killed before (Jeremy Davies is definitely vying for the most irritating portrayal of a character ever.) There are rumours that this film was butchered for theatrical release and I sincerely hope that this was the case!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>*ZZZzzz... Huh what?*</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well... This movie was quite odd... Ok, I'm quite partial to cerebral movies and I actually understood this film and its concept. But still it doesen't make me actually like it. So the whole "You hate it cause you don't understand" line doesen't really apply to me. Cause I did understand! When the credits started rolling the only thing that popped in my head was "So?"...When I went to watch this film, I was expecting something slower and more "dramatic" than a full out Sci-fi thriller. I read the reviews, but still kept an open mind, since like I mentioned before I like "thinking" movies...So I sit down and the film starts. No title credits. At first I thought that it was the projector's screw up, but incidentally the film is supposed to start like that. Ok. Doesen't really affect the film in my oppinion, but at least its a way to already grab the interest of some people. So i became intrigued. But then after 20 minutes of monotonous dialogue and events, I was allready looking at my watch. The film was unfortunately extremely boring. Nothing really happened. It did manage to capture my attention at some parts, even to the point that I was once again intrigued and hoping that the film would suddenly take off and things would actually happen at a regular pace.I understand some people enjoy slow movies, and I also have no problem with films that decide to take a slower pace to build characters and reveal plot at key moments instead of grand-slam action with big breasted women donning two hand held cannons, blowing aliens to pieces in order to save humanity from an onslought of alien invaders... (Though I do like those movies too. :D) But, this film was slower than slow. I mean, you can even hear the actors deliberatly spacing their words in order to drag out the conversation. Much like "Can...You...Get.....(shot of Solaris)........That?" This was too much to bear for me, but I managed to watch the movie to its completion. Even though I nodded off a couple of times, only to wake up and see that the main character hasn't even finnished his first sentence yet.Then theres the whole point of the film. Yes, its a thinking persons film. In a way. But if you manage to stay awake, its not really that hard to figure out. There are no clear answers given, but through out the conversations, you get the idea what they're talking about.: "What is being human?" "Human, Clone, alien, does it really matter?" "What makes you, YOU?" "Are you only a compilation of memories, residing in a physical body, thus proving that an individual is a sum of his upbringing and surrounding? Or do you have soul, with a predetermined fate, created by a diety?" "Or are we all just someones dream?" The film poses some great conversation topics. But the film doesen't really express them too well in my oppinion. It doesen't smack you in the face as if they're going "See?! This is how it is!!!" its more like "Well... It could be this... Or this... Or perhaps that... uh... What do you think?"In my oppinion thinking movies should pose a lot of questions, but they should also try to answer some of them sometimes. Its easy to pose questions in film. (Basically look at the monolith in 2001: A Space Oddesey. Kubrick intentionally left it without explenation. He wanted people to be totally confused) It's harder to answer them... And thats when films like "The sixth Sense" shine. They pose interesting questions, AND THEY ANSWER THEM! *Shock* *horror* How could this be? Well, because the writer thought it out. He realised that its a lot more fulfilling that a film actually does a bit of the cerebral work on behalf of the audience, so that they can atleast enjoy the film. Films that usually lack answers are usually met with more scorn than films that do have answer. I'm not saying that all films that lack answers are bad. I'm just saying that sometimes, when a film poses so many questions, and doesen't even ATTEMPT to answer any of them, audiences feel cheated.Solaris did not have any personal stand point. It didn't have any of its own oppinions on the questions it itself asks. And I'm not talking about questions like "What is Solaris?" I'm talking about the "Humanity questions" The things this film basically was about. They should have atleast tried to prove something. Not just post questions. So when the credits rolled I was "So? What does it mean to be human?"The film does make you think. And it is filmed very well. Solaris is beautiful. And the base is creepy and lonely. But the dialogue. The pacing, the actual flow of the film was lacking.Oh well, this movie was a dissapointment in my oppinion. But sometimes when they try to score a hit, they miss...</fullReview>

		<date>2002-12-31</date>
		<username>iain2345</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Did we see the same movie? I loved it!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay, nobody actually chews any scenery in this film, and there are no big, loud explosions, shoot-outs or fist-fights. Only one person screams or yells, and only for a minute or two. By the hollywood formula then, this is a bad movie....By the standard of intelligent and stimulating film, however, this thing is a gem. It's not about extremes of anger or violence, but about the ways people live and cope with tragic and even blameworthy events day-to-day. Lem, like a sci-fi Camus, has found surprising qualities in the life right under our nose, and, in seeing them, we find something more real and telling than any description of people in more overtly painful, but much less likely circumstance.Some critics have complained about the "artsy" Kubrickian style of direction, but they are, in my opinion, only noticing the similarity of the sets to those of 2001, and the quietness of the soundtrack. Soderberg uses the camera as a recorder of events as they happen, physically present with the actors as some non-character point-of-view, and he lets his microphones record, essentially, the "found" sound of life in the space-station. Soderberg's style then is clearly descended, not from Stanley Kubrick, but Robert Altman, and such a direct style is anything but artsy.All in all, I give this film a 9. I never give anything a 10....</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I don't understand the other viewers' comments saying this was a horrible film. Yes, I was expecting more and for the story to go deeper than it did. Yes, there was some confusing plot elements (who was Gordon's visitor? how did the other scientist die? what happened to the security team that visited? what drugs was Snow on?!) that become even more confusing when you look at the filming script available online which diverges greatly from what finally appeared on screen. Despite that, the film raises some interesting questions about what would happen if our memories became embodied and developed their own consciousness...do they have a separate existence outside of our mind? Can they grow or develop beyond the confines of our perception of the past? The film could have been much more and although people here say it was boring, I was dying for another 1/2 hour to go more deeply into some issues...things were wrapped up too quickly and neatly for my tastes. Guess I'll be hunting for the original Russian film next!Parting words: Go see the film and make up your own mind. Considering how many really awful movies are made (Pluto Nash, The Hot Chick, Sorority Boys, etc.) calling this a "horrible film" is completely unwarranted. It may not be a "10" but it won't be a waste of your time.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-12-11</date>
		<username>darth87</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>What if the Creator is me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>--Spoilers below--The popular theme of `I am God' is taken to extremes in Solaris. The movie depicts a world built upon a nihilistic point-of-view. In the absence of objective truth, humans are left with only their subjective perceptions and the entire life experience becomes an object of humanistic creation. Therefore, human existence lies within boundaries of the greatest aspirations and the basest desires, yet; the existence is constrained by the finite capacity of the human mind. The philosophy can be summarized as, `We cannot create anything greater than ourselves.'The corporeal visitors in Solaris come from the memories of a human host. Solaris seems to analyze dreams during sleep then creates the visitors based on those dreams and memories. The central character, Dr. Kelvin, experiences the Solaris effect via the visitation of his `resurrected' wife. She has been dead for years but Solaris creates her exactly as he remembers her-and therein lays the rub. As an extension of his memory she is more automaton than human. The familiarity of her physical appearance and social responses are comforting and intoxicating. Yet the overall experience lacks the lightness of spontaneity and serendipity. Dr. Kelvin becomes trapped in a `heaven' of his own creation.There are many other themes depicted in the movie related too this central theme. If you enjoy movies that require the audience to feel and think about what they feel--then see this movie.Best Regards, Darth87 December 2002</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-12-10</date>
		<username>spinin</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't hate it cause it's beautiful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Human nature makes us so constricted. We want everything nicely categorized and neatly packaged. Most of all, we need to have control and understanding over everything in life, otherwise we feel frustrated and are unable to function. I am at least talking about the majority here. I would like to think that I am different, but nobody's perfect. SOLARIS is a beautiful film that is already well on its way to becoming the most underrated movie of the year thanks to the usual unsubstantiated complaints that it is boring or makes no sense. To those not used to films that stray from typical Hollywood movie conventions and to those too lazy to think or to try to interpret the movie themselves, SOLARIS would be worse than death or public speaking. To those open minded enough to understand that film is also art and can be used to convey thought, SOLARIS may be a great experience.The plot is only the set-up. Psychiatrist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is sent to a space station to investigate the strange behavior of the crew, with whom contact has been lost. The crew's mission was to study a mysterious planet called Solaris. Upon his arrival, Chris finds that only two people, Snow and Gordon, are still alive, while the rest of the crew either committed suicide or died mysteriously. During his first night there, Chris is visited by his dead wife, Rheya. She is not a ghost, but seemingly a real person. Apparently, Solaris is able to read people's thoughts and recreate loved-ones from their memories. The `visitors' appear how they were remembered rather than how they really were.The plot does not develop much beyond that. The film becomes a meditation on the nature of the situation. I am not sure what to make of Snow's character, but it is clear that Gordon is terrified by everything that is happening even though she does not comprehend it. She is eager to destroy the planet and any visitors without even trying to understand the situation. Chris is much more open minded, but may be going mad. In the early scenes back on earth, he is portrayed as sad and lonely. With the reappearance of his dead wife on the space station, he eagerly seeks a second chance.I think that Soderbergh has done an amazing job here especially the way he blurs the lines between reality and Chris' thoughts, memories, and dreams. The film has his usual steadi-cam style with some beautiful and fascinating images. The cinematography and haunting music were simply captivating, especially in the scene where Chris first dreams of his wife. The film is deliberately paced, but it is not slow and boring. It allowed my eyes to wander from one side of the screen to the other and completely absorb the images.I have not read the original novel or seen Tarkovsky's version so I cannot make any of those comparisons. However, 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY is one of my favorite films and SOLARIS evoked many of the same themes and recreated some of the same stunning images (while watching, I thought about how great it would be to see 2001 on the big screen). You cannot really compare SOLARIS to 2001, but I'm sure that Soderbergh was never thinking about surpassing Kubrick's film. I do think that this is his best movie along with TRAFFIC. I think he went in a different direction and succeeded on almost every level. The same can be said of George Clooney who, like Brad Pitt and Johnny Depp, is fighting his Sexiest Man in the World image with a good performance in a risky movie (although you wouldn't think so from the excessive shots of his rear end).Without getting into a specific discussion of the film's themes, the general meanings conveyed by SOLARIS relate back to what I said in the first paragraph. The film is meant to question human existence and our nature in the universe. It questions our need to explain the unexplainable and our fear of what we do not understand. It portrays humans as creatures with limitations that have a ridiculous need to always be right. I don't know if Solaris is meant to represent god or the unknown, but it is something that humans are not able to comprehend with everything we know on earth. By the end of the movie Chris realizes that he can no longer live the way he has and opens his mind to new possibilities. That may be the only way at another chance with his wife.If you feel intimidated by a thought provoking film that will force you to be an active participant and will not cater to your expectations, rent SPIDER-MAN. If you are specifically looking for sci-fi movies with gadgets and explosions then wait for STAR TREK: NEMESIS or even go to DIE ANOTHER DAY (a pretty sci-fi Bond movie). I'm sure there are people who understood SOLARIS and still disliked it. That's fine. I simply disagree with quick and irrational judgments of this film based on misinterpretations. I do not think that SOLARIS is anything completely new or revolutionary, but it felt very fresh. My enjoyment level was just about as high as it could have been throughout. I did wish it had been longer (that's right!) since it went by so fast. Maybe then Soderbergh could have gone even further with his themes. However, the threatened masses already don't know what to make of it and dismiss it as unclear or self-indulgent, so maybe it's for the best this way. SOLARIS gets a 9 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Li-1</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An intriguing sci-fi/drama.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>7.5 out of 10For all the hype thrown upon George Clooney's derriere and the film's lack of mainstream appeal, Steven Soderbergh's remake of Stanislaw Lem's classic novel is a worthy venture. George Clooney stars as Chris Kelvin, a psychologist who, upon a request from a friend, heads to a space station orbiting the planet Solaris. On board, he discovers his friend and another man dead, as well as two survivors, Snow (Jeremy Davies) and Gordon (Viola Davis). But most startlingly, his deceased wife, Rhea (Natasha Mcelhone) re-appears on the space station, not knowing how she arrived or where she came from. Kelvin is shocked, and believes Solaris itself may have been responsible for her "resurrection." He and the remaining crew question if this "copy" is even a human being, but he sees her reappearance as a chance for redemption.This mixture of sci-fi and drama isn't as successful as either Contact or 2001, but it's an intelligent, thoughtful drama with intriguing concepts and theories. The performances are good, especially Clooney and Mcelhone, who develop just enough chemistry to make a believable couple. The film pays a little too much focus toward the past relationship between Kelvin and his wife (the direction during some of these scenes is sometimes rather indulgent), and not quite enough speculation on what Solaris is. But the film is smart and engaging, daring enough to question our perception of humanity and how we judge a person's existence, capping off with a nicely ambiguous ending that's sure to spark much discussion. Similar to Spielberg's A.I., I see a more positive response from audiences in the future.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-12-06</date>
		<username>byron_t</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>For Art's Sake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For those looking for Star Wars or Men in Black, this movie is not for you. The classification of `Science Fiction/Thriller' is somewhat misleading. While it is science fiction, the film is much too cerebral to be called a `thriller.' In truth, this film is more a testament to the power Soderbergh has in Hollywood than anything else. It's not that the film is bad, but it certainly is not `major world wide release' material. This is both a critique and a compliment for the film. On the one hand, the movie going public could do with more challenging films, movies that it takes a few post viewing hours to wrap your mind around. On the other hand, presenting a movie this inaccessible to the general public runs the risk of a financial and professional failing. Thus, that Soderbergh could make it and release it during the Christmas movie season speaks volumes about how much pull he has (and justifiably so) in the industry.As for the movie itself, as with all Soderbergh films it is exceptionally well crafted (Traffic is, in my opinion, the most finely crafted film made in the last 20 years). Fans of Soderbergh will not be disappointed by either the visual or atmospheric elements he brings to bear. That begs the question whether visual and artistic merit are sufficient criteria with which to judge a film. The answer is; it depends. In a film such as Ron Fircke's Baraka, where there is no dialogue and there are no (specific) characters, the thematic elements can only be conveyed through visual and audio images. Therefore, visual and artistic merit are the only criteria you can use to judge the film, and that suffices. However, in a traditional film with characters, dialogue and action there is an expectation for thematic cohesion that Solaris seems to lack. Because the ideas are vague and the plot non-linier, very few people will come out of this movie with a strong sense of what actually happened and what it all meant. On the surface, that seems like not such a bad thing. Strong art (and despite its wide release this is undoubtedly an `art film') should leave you thinking, discussing and wondering. The problem is that if you are unable to come to any cohesive, arguable conclusions after you have done the thinking and discussing, the value of the film comes into question. If the only value of a film that includes dialogue, character and action is for the visual and atmospheric quality, why should the former be included?All of this is to say that we cannot simply be impressed with Soderbergh's camera work and call the film good. Nor is it enough to say, `Wow, that film really made me think, it must be good.' Rather, the director and writers should use the medium they employ to convey a message, and at some level that message must be obtainable by the audience they are trying to communicate with. If the film, even after it has been discussed and analyzed by discerning minds continues to be incoherent, it has failed in to communicate and thus failed completely.The unavoidable comparison with Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey illustrates this point. I first saw 2001 when I was twelve and I'm not sure what was more confusing, the movie or why I had watched the whole thing. I had no idea whatsoever about what the film could mean. However, I sat down with my father afterward and he pointed out some of the ideas and meaning. Ideas such as that the film showed the progression of man from beast to human to whatever enlightened being Dave becomes at the end of 2001. He showed me how the obelisk was either a catalyst for or a representation of these huge leaps in humanities advancements. As our discussion progressed, the ideas of the film fell from confused images to a cohesive theme. Certainly not one that was easily accessible or capable of being grasped without thought or effort, but after the effort was applied I knew, even at a young age, what was being communicated to me. In short, the director and writer had connected. The power of that moment stays with me even years later. Solaris, unfortunately, never lets the viewer (no matter how discerning) make that discovery or that connection. You are left convinced that the film had something to say but despairing that you will never know what it was. There is an overall lack of internal consistency so at no point can you track enough evidences to a defendable conclusion. It's not so much that there are inconsistencies, but that you don't have enough evidence to support any particular idea convincingly. It is the worst kind of argument: one with neither a conclusion nor enough evidence to support a conclusion.Some will argue that that is precisely the nature of the film. The fact that there is no solid answer is not only justifiable but also desirable. For that argument to be true, however, we must accept that the film either does not give us enough information or the information is contradictory. If that is the case, it lacks the fundamental aspect that makes science fiction believable, internal consistency. The viewer is left with only confusion and chaos, neither of which justifies the medium used to present, nor the time taken to view, the material.If you appreciate the visual and atmospheric elements in film this movie is worth watching. If you are going for the plot or themes you will likely be disappointed. There is a subset of viewers out there who will completely enjoy this film for its existential elements and unanswerable questions. However, for those who might be tempted to see this film because they anticipate some form of intellectual edification, just rent 2001 and call my dad with any questions you might have about it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>This movie makes a statement about what is important in life--and it is not truth. Kelvin makes the choice to remain on Solaris with this "wife" whom he knows is not really her. Instead he gives in to it.What is frightening about this film is that it is a metaphor for the human condition in general. It says we are all like Kelvin, trapped in a world of our own perceptions, and that all that really matters is whether we are happy with what we percieve or not. Solaris gives Kelvin not his deepest desire, but the perception of having that desire. He makes the choice to accept that, and the movie invites us all to give up on Truth, Responsibility, and Purpose, and just live in a personal world of our own psychological comfort zone.One is reminded of the scene in _The Matrix_ where the main character is offered the blue pill or the red pill. The Red Pill is Truth, the Blue Pill allows him to wake up tomorow morning back in his own bed in that fake "Matrix" world, none the wiser. In that movie, the main character chooses the Red Pill and Truth, even though it is painful. In this movie, Kelvin chooses the Blue Pill, and the lie, just because it is psychologically satisfying.This is a great film, as to directing, cinematography, acting etc. and will be an art house classic. However, the message is false and frightening to contemplate.</fullReview>

Man is an animal with long foresight of this fact, but only due to his relatively higher intellect, which can be explained through evolutionary processes. 		<shortDescription>THE BOUNDARIES OF LOVE?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Why is it that intelligent domestic films with a European sensibility so often fail with American audiences? The answer obviously lies in our society's apparent need to dismiss any thought-provoking film's ability to entertain, and Steven Soderberg's Solaris is one such effort. My enjoyment of this 99 minutes of superb cinema lies in its living, breathing organic structure that mirrors the passion and unpredictability of true love. This film intends to appeal to an audience's sense of exploration and emotion on many levels, and not necessarily in one viewing. Immediate comparisons that come to mind are Ridley Scott's `Blade Runner', Steven Spielberg's `Minority Report' ? even touches of director Nicolas Roeg's early works are present in the sometimes non-linear, flashback storytelling structure.The ensemble casting and acting is fine throughout, particularly Viola Davis' sure portrayal of Helen Gordon, which brought to mind Sigourney Weaver's raw, emotional Ellen Ripley in 1979's `Alien'. The entire cast interacts with a sense as instinctual as a relay team passing a hand baton. George Clooney's Chris Kelvin feels completely authentic, and his true believability and sense of emotional depth are at the core of what makes Solaris work. His other half in this worldly examination of love ? actress Natascha McElhone - is perfectly cast as wife Rheaya Kelvin. Their chemistry facilitates the audience's need to believe in the intimacy of their relationship. The story cannot work without believing in this marriage, and the scenes that establish the union are truly naturalistic, almost voyeuristic in execution.Solaris is forward thinking in everything it explores ? Soderberg confidently tells this story with a knowing that audiences will catch up with his total senses storytelling style ? if not now, certainly at some point in the not so distant future.</fullReview>

		<username>EVANOC</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Soderbergh's sci-fi exercise, eye candy and nothing else</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After just seeing Solaris, I have worked and re-worked my thoughts on Steven Soderbergh to a point that I think is finally expressible. Let me start by acknowledging Soderbergh's obvious and pure talent; it is total, visually evocative as well as thematically minded, and his films are often a pleasure to watch for their keen cinematic intellect. However, I tend to think, particularly after Solaris, that Soderbergh is still searching to channel that boundless, preternatural cinematic gift into his great masterpiece. His career has been spotty so far. Between films, and even within films, he can go from inspired to pretentious film-school brat in a matter of shots. His more successful ventures (at least the ones I have appreciated the most: Out of Sight, The Limey, and Traffic) have contained only a modicum of that generic, `indie' (which I use pejoratively) and a lot of worthwhile bits. But Soderbergh is still searching for something, a genre, a style, an expressive voice, maybe even a muse. I like to think of his movies as exercises. Traffic was an exercise in using an Altman-esque sense of scope and interlocking stories to politically condemn the American involvement in the drug trade. Out of Sight was an exercise in creating a cool, up-to-date crime caper and giving two of our sexiest and most bankable STARS meaty roles. Sex, lies, and videotape was an exercise in seeing exactly how far the early independent filmmaking scene could be stretched. Et cetera, et cetera. Solaris is just another installment in his succession of filmic exercises.All of the director's usual production values are in place in Solaris, and they are more effective than ever: The jittery handheld camera for intimate scenes, the blue filters for emotional distance, and the fabulous movement-cinematography (this time, as usual, by Soderbergh, with nom de cine). Solaris' (and Soderbergh's) best visual creation is the solaris itself, a swirling nebula of pink and orange. He keeps returning to this image, as if he knew it would become the one with the most staying power.I mentioned all of these visual components first, because they fully overshadow any plot or characterizations that might be present in the movie. Essentially, Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is a psychologist asked to journey to Solaris, a space station floating dangerous close to the aforementioned pink nebula. He has been summoned because of some extraordinary goings-on at the space station that basically remain unnamed throughout. To add a dimension to Kelvin, he is grieving over the loss of his wife (played by Natascha McElhone in a very muted, nearly plastic performance). The reason Kelvin was summoned into space stays as nebulous as the solaris: weird things have been happening and the remaining crew members (Viola Davis and Jeremy Davies, both passable in their parts and well-cast) have been visited by facsimiles of their deceased loved ones. All three reach a psychological breaking point when Kelvin is visited by his dead wife and ethical issues over her existence, the fine line between life and death, and her proposed termination arise.That is basically all there is to the plot, and why an emphasis is better placed on Solaris' production values. This seems like an aesthetic, stylistic exercise for Soderbergh. He is merely playing with eye candy, cloaking a thin script (a supposedly thin adaptation of Tarkovsky's classic film of the same title) in a lot of evocative stuff. But there isn't much here, not much for audience and director alike to sink their teeth into, and it seems as if Soderbergh knows that.To hit upon George Clooney for a moment, this is one of his more serious-minded performances but that by no means suggests it is his best. Clooney, one of the sexiest men in movies by default, has risen above all his star power by making the most consistently smart movie choices of anyone in Hollywood. I don't know if this is as smart a move for him as, say, David O. Russell's Three Kings or the Coen's O Brother, Where Art Thou?, but it is interesting and shows balls. He tampers down his inherent charisma in Solaris, but when he allows it to shine through, those moments constitute some of the best scenes in the film. Whatever you make of his performance, it is a gutsy one for a star of his caliber, even if the material isn't particularly groundbreaking or even well-constructed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>"Solaris" Is One Er, Uh, Unique Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I figured it was time to finally make a comment on a film here on IMDB. After all, I use the comments of others to get a feeling for many of the films I see before I bother heading to the multiplex or video store.It's ironic that "Solaris" is the first film I've commented on because, as I left the theatre, I realised that it was ALSO the first time I've ever felt that the time I invested into the film was a complete waste.Oh, I "get it." I know the questions Soderbergh is asking. They're not new: What is the difference between being alive and being dead? Just how wide is the chasm between "reality" and our perception thereof? Did god create us, did we create god, or does it even matter at all? Who are we to define what it means to be "human?" I "get it." I just don't care, because we have no reason to. We don't care about Kelvin, we don't care about his wife, we don't care about this spaceship, or this planet.This movie was the retro-beatnik that sits in the local independent coffee shop and recites off-kilter poetry because he likes to hear his own unorthodoxy."Solaris" is a big fluff of cotton candy which, if it weren't laced with layers of "look what I can do" cleverness, would have been enough to satisfy me. Unfortunately, Soderbergh mistook "vague, disorienting and disconnected" for "deep"...and in the process, wasted an hour and a half of my life. "Battlefield Earth," for example, was a cookie-cutter, amateur recruitment video-slash-miniseries pretending to be a movie...but I was even able to find SOMETHING redeeming about it. "Solaris" is by no means the worst movie I've ever seen. It's just the most worthless and empty experience I've had the misfortune of paying for to date. And I've seen some really vapid films in my time ("2001" comes to mind)Consider this your warning. If pretension and psuedo-intellectualism is your cup of tea, you'll love this film. Otherwise, you'd probably do well to avoid it.</fullReview>
	</review>

Like Joel Siegel, I wanted to stand and applaud, like Ebert, I found myself in deep reflection....I will see it again! I am disturbed however, that after seeing the film at 11 A.M. on its opening day, that Imdb had 77 votes just fifteen minutes later, many of them "one's"....and I must question the honesty of such participation even though I repeat that the film is not for those who are intellectually challenged. 		<shortDescription>There's no "there" there...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***WARNING - POSSIBLE SPOILERS ENCLOSED***I went with an open, hopeful mind, having read that this was "cerebral" sci-fi that dealt with Big Questions. Not!First of all, it was overly derivative, e.g.: a) The "Third Expedition" segment of "The Martian Chronicles." b) The penultimate scene in "2001: A Space Odyssey" (the hotel room that was obviously the construct of an incomprehensible being). c) "The Monkey's Paw," a hundred-year-old short story that is a cautionary tale about being careful what you wish for. d) The "false memory" angle dealt with in "Blade Runner."Being derivative isn't necessarily a sin, as long as you deliver...but this movie doesn't. Rheya's dawning awareness of who she "was," and what she really is, is the only mildly interesting angle to be found in this pointless, aimless plot.And the whole question of Solaris itself is given incredibly short shrift. It's obviously a very odd "rogue" celestial body that's wandered into our solar system, and long enough ago for humans to have placed an elaborate observation structure in orbit, but we aren't told anything about it. It's just...there.I'm not a big fan of George Clooney, but this disappointing film is hardly his fault - DeNiro or Edward Norton would have had trouble making the character interesting/believable.No, the blame goes to writer/director Steven Soderbergh. It's hard to believe this is the same guy who wrote and directed "Sex, Lies and Videotape" back in 1989.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-12-01</date>
		<username>superjxiv</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderfully crafted, but too slow to enjoy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's a difficult job for a movie critic, or a critic of anything, when the product has artistic merit, but the method in which that product is brought forth is incredibly painful. Think of an enema that ends up looking like the Mona Lisa. `Solaris' must be the slowest, most drawn out movie to come out since Stanley Kubrick died. It even echoes Kubrick's brilliant, yet taxing, `2001.' Care and detail are given to ever pause between every word, every gesture, and every moving part of the characters, the titular planet, and the space station orbiting it. Chris Kelvin is asked to figure out what went wrong on that space station, why the crew has cut off communications with Earth. Arriving at the station, he finds two dead bodies, and two remaining crew. They are of little help. Chris goes to bed and dreams of his wife, who died some years before. He awakes to find her lying next to him, as if nothing had happened.The main question posed in `Solaris' isn't whether or not she's really his wife. She's not. His wife is dead. All this new girl will ever be is a reflection of how Kelvin remembers her, not who she really was. The question is, do we ever communicate enough to ever really know someone.Steven Soderberg always takes an interesting approach to the idea of memory and flashbacks. One of the film's pluses is that the flashbacks aren't there to supplement the storytelling. The flashbacks, which show the young couples passionate first encounter, their playful banter as the relationship blossoms, and a few needless shots of Clooney's ass, are shown to us as the memories themselves race through Chris's and his wife's mind.While all these ideas and themes have a lot of potential, the film merely sets them up and fails to provide us with any real follow through. Chris soon becomes convinced that he can make up for past mistakes, that he has been given a second chance. This section of the film denies him all the intelligence we'd expect as he fervently tries to keep this new girl alive.A mistake of this movie was its wide release, where it will not find an audience. It's deep and meaningful, and it shows us insights into humanity that most movies gloss over. That's good. However, it's nearly stationary pace, repetitious visuals, and the quiet performances by the entire cast hinders its entertainment value. That's too bad. A lot of critics and filmmakers seem to forget that most people watch movies as a form of entertainment, not a as a means of mediation. The best movies are the deep, meaningful, and artistic ones that can still entertain us.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Dmitri Plotnikov (dmitri@plotnix.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Does everything possible to keep you in the theater</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The original Solaris by Andrei Tarkovsky is a cult classic. Rent it at Blockbuster and compare. As with all Tarkovsky's movies, it is made for the "enlightened" and does not even make an attempt to win over anybody else. You'll see how much more of the story Tarkovsky leaves off the screen - for the patient viewer to reconstruct. Your attention will be challenged by seemingly endless visual sequences. At times the dialog is so rich with different ideas that you need to rewind a few times to simply hear it all. Thus the Tarkovsky's version would not work for general audiences - it requires too much commitment from the viewer. I saw it in the 70s, people were walking out of the theater - just as expected.Soderbergh knows all that and makes everything humanly possible to adjust the movie to the general public's tastes. He focuses on the most fundamental ideas. He sticks to the tightest, most straightforward storyline. He cuts the movie himself with the precision of Eric Clapton's guitar. He also knows that he will lose audiences if he fails to entertain them all the time, so he casts two undisputedly beautiful actors: Clooney and Natascha McElhone, augments the couple with a wonderfully funny sidekick (Jeremy Davies). He turns every frame into a glamor shot, adds romantic love scenes (with nudity, mind you), a state-of-the-art sci-fi soundtrack and elaborate computer graphics... and still people walk out of the theater. My heart breaks. I fear that before long movie makers will just give up.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>His best since Traffic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**SPOILERS!!!** Soderbergh has a tendency to produce good movies and bad movies, so I was somewhat worried when I walked into the movie. It started off giving me a bad impression, but completely saved itself at the very end. Watching the movie, I was consistently reminded of the Myst game series. Not for stylistic reasons, but simply the overall detached tone seemed to be very similar. This movie is an example of Soderbergh's incredible ability to imply things very subtly. Half the plot is hinted at through flashbacks, and for those people who like to think, a lot is told in so little time. This movie makes no attempt to explain the science fiction it incorporates. Rather, it spends its short time explaining the psychology of the humans and Solaris. People going in expecting a sci-fi will be greatly disappointed if they are expecting realism; this is a psychological movie, and explains that well. My favorite line was the last part, where George Clooney asks, "Am I alive, or dead?" It doesn't matter, because if he believes he is happy, then it is of no consequence whether or not he is dead. This is how the entire movie is; even we do not know whether he is actually at Earth and dreaming, or still in Solaris. It is an exploration of the human mind, and how it reacts. This is the type of thing that Soderbergh often attempts, and when he succeeds, delivers a</fullReview>

		<date>2002-12-01</date>
		<username>Brett Perkins (Kingtokeyshawn)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Cloaked in Beauty</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Heaven. No, not the feeling that I got when I came out of the movie, but the overall theme for me. But even though I did not feel heaven, I did find myself provoked to ask many questions, listen to many answers, and ponder them both. Surprisingly this movie is gripping, especially with all the warnings people have put out to the impatient about being bored. In comparison to many of the action packed crap put out today that is utterly more boring with their fiber thin plots and ambiguous reasons for creation this movie rises above the rest although it admittedly has a more methodical pace than most films, and I liked that. It gave me time to appreciate the film before the credits rolled.The acting was superb, just superb around everything else. A key line for me was paraphrased here, "There are no answers, just choices." I was impressed and bought into Jeremy Davies character of Snow too, which may sound puzzling to many of you as it seems the majority feels he was an annoyance but I liked him. Oh yeah, and Clooney and Mchelone were excellent as well, but I think there performances speak for themselves.Another thing that is almost necessary for a film to become one of my favorites is atmosphere, and this movie has it like a five star restaurant. There is just this feeling that is in the air, like it has jumped off screen and into the theater. The ideas that are contained in this film, interpreted in any opinion, are truly refreshing and purely amazing from any point of view. I would have to say as a gauge, if you liked AI there are a lot of similarities that would increase your chances of enjoying this movie as well.Not everyone feels this way, but the religious overtones standout in the film for me. Whether it was intentional or not, or whether I added most of the overtones myself the planet Solaris itself carries more than just scientific weight. And still more, there is a thoroughly convincing and deep character study about human relationships and the need for communication. I especially enjoyed the scene where Clooney has a flashback of his wife and himself walking down the street, there was just something hauntingly emotional about it. Steven Soderbergh should be commended, AGAIN!! for his continued drive to express something and his ability to make us think. His vision and talent to the art form of film is something to be cherished. I also found Cliff Martinez's score to capture each scene exquisitely and his music to be emotionally resounding. Look for his next great score in Narc and his last great one in Traffic.And does anyone have a clue about the doorknob on the train?</fullReview>
	</review>
