		<username>Damian Mihai</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Never remake a masterpiece</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Solaris is Steven Soderbergh's adaptation of Stanislaw Lem's novel "Solaris" and remake of Andrei Tarkovsky's Cannes prized "Solyaris". Considering these fact there are too ways of approaching this film: reading Lem's novel/viewing Tarkovsky's movie or none of both. I myself, doing the former two, was very disappointed by this movie. Although this movie is significantly better than most movies that come out of Hollywood it is utterly sloppy compared to Tarkovsky's adaptation. Shure, this movie get's you thinking more than most popcorn flicks, and yes, this is not your average action-adventure-E.T. killing S.F. but the movie fails to focus on the questions it raises.One of Lem's main theme's in his book is man's inherited incapacity of communicating with profoundly alien entities. And profound alien entity is just what Solaris is. That is right - Solaris is not just the planet where most of the film is set but Solaris, or better yet, Solaris' ocean is an entity, a being, possibly a rational being. It is capable of reading human thoughts and capable of forging "real life illusions" of friends or family members that haunt the minds of the astronauts living on the space station on Solaris. The fact that "Solaris" sends these messengers out, and the fact that the final solution of the characters is to destroy them signifies just this impossibility to establish a connection with the planetary mind. Now you might not get all this just by watching Soderbergh's movie simply because it fails to illustrate these problems either by means of plot, dialogue or plain visual effects. In fact the movie is very poor at explaining what Solaris, the purpose for it is researched and completely cuts out an important part of the original plot that explains the mysterious encounters of a pilot in Solaris' atmosphere.This remake is one hour shorter than Tarkovsky's version and unfortunately it shows. Some people compared this title with 2001: A Space Odysee because of it's long cuts and it's slow and little action. In fact comparing it with Solyaris one can only have the impression that the director made a bet that he could get all the story in an under 100 minutes film.Unfortunately the result lacks consistency. It is hard for the viewer to follow the themes of the movie unless he is already familiar with them from the book or from "that old Russian movie".The director hoped this will turn out to be a smart movie like his previous "Traffic" but he ended up with this pseudo art movie. It is too low key and psychological for "Star Wars" fans and too Hollywood for "2001" fans.Rated 4 out of 10 for mediocre, better luck next time,never remake something that's already perfect the way it is</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Intelligent, moving sci-fi</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>CONTAINS SPOILERS! What an outstanding piece of work. This is pure sci-fi: take a wild concept - what if our memories of lost love ones could become real and take on their own lives? - and then follow the idea to its logical conclusion, as realistically as possible.Despite a slow start this film scores, largely because of the outstanding portrayals of its two central characters, Chris (Clooney) and Rheya (McElhone). Of the two, McElhone is the mesmerising heart of this film, delivering an understated but electrifying performance as a new being struggling to understand what she is, and struggling to negotiate strange memories of her pain-wracked relationship with Chris.The parallel stories of their relationship past and present play out beautifully and almost every scene delivers a thoroughly convincing emotional bombshell. And no, it isn't a chick flick. This is grown-up film-making. It feels a lot like a play - dominated by long conversations between the two main characters. But it never drags and never gets boring. On the contrary, it is totally gripping because it commands such belief in its characters and their situation.Hats off to George for a nuanced, heartfelt performance and for being enough of a professional to give over so much screen time to McElhone. There are long shots here of conversations between these two in which we see nothing of Clooney at all - just McElhone's extraordinarily beautiful, haunting face, studying her reactions as he speaks. And it works. This film will stay with you for days.Highlight: Clooney's anguish when he discovers that Rheya has aborted their child (paralleled at the end when Rheya discovers that he killed her first "copy") - a powerful scene and the kind of acting you rarely see in Hollywood movies. We need more of this stuff.</fullReview>

		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>There are no answers, only choices.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Some Spoilers are here.Solaris is a sci-fi love story. I already hear the collective groans of a populace conditioned to expect violence and 1 dimensional characters in their sci-fi genre. But Solaris isn't interested in alien civilizations or in a far away time where science has taken the "man" out of human. It is very much about the humanity of the proceedings and if you don't dig that well...this isn't for you.We follow the journey of Kelvin(George Clooney in a stunning turn from his usual performances). Kelvin is a staunch atheist "realist". He is sent to a spacecraft that is studying a planet called Solaris. It seems that the crew on Solaris are having deep mental issues and Kelvin is a renowned shrink. Kelvin's friend was the lead scientist on the ship and he has committed suicide. Kelvin is supposed to be the objective assessor of the problems on board. The only catch is that neither he nor anyone on Earth have any idea what is really facing the crew. Now that could be a set up for the next Alien picture where the climax involves Clooney and the crew kicking ass and taking names. Not here. Solaris isn't a goo dripping monster. Solaris is a very benign looking beautiful planet that just exists with only one catch. Those near it are being visited by dead relatives, friends, etc. This is where the story begins. We see through Clooney's "ghost" a tragic romance in the making. Clooney is visited by his deceased wife and through flashbacks and conversations between the two we find out that she had mental issues and committed suicide. I won't go into all of the hows and whys of the suicide but needless to say it is a great story told faithfully by the movie.Kelvin can't see past his own love and feelings of guilt over his wife's death. Gordon the lead scientist on the trip can't see past her paranoia and fear. In a few short days Kelvin goes from supposedly helping the crew deal with their issues to exposing himself as the one with the deepest problems of them all. The questions that are posed are gigantic and the answers to those types of questions can't really be answered in a movie. Knowing this the film never insults us with cheeky solutions. What is life? Kelvin posits that Gordon is a murderer when she "kills" one of the visitors he is saying that existence is all that matters not origin or circumstance. Is it murder? The movie doesn't even begin to say. Kelvin it seems to me was already dead. He died with his wife and he was simply going through the motions of existence. The other character in this piece is Snow who happens to be my favorite character. Snow we come to learn is actually from Solaris. We start out and he is the most human and compassionate of all the characters and at the end we discover that he was the real Snow's visitor and had to kill him in self defense. What does that say? Again the movie leaves it up to us with the confidence that we'll figure that out for ourselves.The movie isn't easy to love. It is slow and contemplative. It never spoon feeds or coddles the viewer. You'll have to put in your own work to enjoy it. Just because it takes place on a spaceship and in the future does not mean it will have a lot of action or explosions. It is simply a study of life and love set in the future with creepy undertones. What is Solaris? The movie never definitely says what the motives of Solaris is. In fact when Clooney asks his apparition friend what Solaris wants he is merely answered with a rhetorical "What makes you think it has to want something?". It isn't for everyone but if it is your style you will indeed love it with a vengeance.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-03-07</date>
		<username>DARREN HORNE</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Solaris Review</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Solaris began life in 1961 as a Polish novel by Stanislaw Lem, then made into a film by Russian director Andrei Tarkovsky in 1972. In this contemporary remake Steven Soderbergh takes the reigns as director, and comes up with a thoughtful and adult film that puts the intelligence back into sci-fi. This is clearly a personal work of passion, and that commitment shines through in every single shot.Dr Chris Kelvin (Clooney) is an emotionally scarred psychologist that is sent to the space station Prometheus that orbits the enigmatic planet Solaris. (In Greek mythology Prometheus is the Titan that created Man and gave them fire, without asking the permission of Zeus. He was punished for 30 thousand years by being chained to a rock and every day an eagle came and ate out his liver, which would then grow back during the night)On arrival he finds his friend has apparently committed suicide and the remaining two crew members are acting very strangely indeed. Kelvin later has a vivid dream about his dead wife Rheya, (McElhoe) who he finds alive and well in bed next to him when he wakes the following morning. The film uses this scenario to explore a plethora of ideas and philosophical issues such as the meaning of life, religion, God, love, as well as what it is that defines a human. Thankfully there is plenty of time for the audience to ponder these issues due to the slow pace and long scenes with no dialogue at all.The restrictive narrative means Clooney fills practically every scene, which works superbly well as this is an emotionally complex film about one mans struggle to come to terms with his wife's death, his memory of that event, and then her unsettling return from the grave. Clooneys performance is fantastic, especially as the wounded widower that is stripped of the twinkly eyed charm (and sometimes his clothes) that we see in the dreamy flashback sequences. This allows him to deliver a raw and vulnerable performance of a man totally heart broken from past experiences.McElhoe is equally as outstanding (and remarkably beautiful) as his mentally unstable wife who has her own difficulties in coming to terms with her existence and place in the universe. The special effects used are of a high standard and used wisely. The space station is a solid and functional stage for the story to be performed on, where as the planet Solaris is a visual feast of exquisite beauty, with mesmerising electric pinks and blues that will literally bring a tear to your eye. It will not appeal to every one. I watched at least two couples leave the already barren cinema, and my girlfriend fell asleep in my lap However, it is a great film for those of us who want more than passive popcorn entertainment, and really should be seen on the big screen. This is an extremely well made, surreal, and philosophical, treat that will pose a lot of questions and hopefully touch your soul. As one of the characters says "There are no answers, only choices". Choose to see this film.</fullReview>

		<username>Critical Eye UK</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Lost in Space. . . 7/10</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(Small spoilers ahead)Proof that there's intelligent life out there ? well, in the American cinema industry at least ? arrives by the plateful with ?Solaris'. Imbued with a special vision and hallmarked throughout with a rare integrity, it's the kind of movie that makes you almost, but not quite forget, the catchpenny rubbish of Mel Gibson and ?Signs'.Unfortunately though, being intelligent is one thing, intelligible, quite another. And where this version of ?Solaris' is concerned, the eclipse of meaning is total.?Solaris' is not, according to Soderbergh, a planet in the conventional sense. But an organism. An organism which draws upon the subconscious mind of those who come too close to it. (Andrei Tarkovsky played it the same way with his 1972 version, though at least as a film-maker battling against the Soviet regime he had a pretty good grasp on how mind-warping can ensue when one is drawn in too close to a monumental ideology).Soderbergh's organism, however, seems unrepresentative of anything at all. It exists. And whilst that's okay, scientifically speaking -- because organisms don't have to have a hidden agenda -- it's anything but okay, dramatically speaking. And that's the problem here: ?Solaris', meant to be a major presence in the movie, has no impact at all -? there's not a single Solaris PoV shot of the spacecraft hovering above it, not a single attempt to stamp its purpose, substance and identity upon the audience's consciousness.(Think back, if you will, to how Kubrick handled this kind of thing with HAL in 2001: A Space Odyssey -- the sudden HAL PoV shot, lip-reading the mouths of the astronauts, is as cinematically chilling as anything Hitchcock ever contrived).Here though, Solaris doesn't, er, do anything. Glimpsed through the spacecraft's windows, it changes colour, and in the closing sequence seems more vivid and more active than before. Why though is not explained: the organism simply ?is', so whether it's getting excited about preying upon human minds, or hyper-charged at the interaction of those minds with itself, is a non-sequitur: we don't know what it cares about, so we've nothing to care about, either.Little wonder, then, that Clooney is reduced to looking worried and confused and then even more worried and more confused, whilst McElhone pops up, or does not pop up, in sequences so reminiscent of ?Last Year In Marienbad' that you begin to wonder if Resnais, not Tarkovsky, was the director Soderbergh had in mind when embarking on this odyssey into what is real and what is not.That said though, what ?Solaris' certainly isn't is a cogent exploration of themes like love and hate, loss and redemption, or even religion and spirituality: though you sense Soderbergh and his producers would like to think ?Solaris' touches on all these, viewers less inclined to self-delusion will note that instead of some grand and enigmatic narrative arc, there is instead only a giant black hole here into which collapses all sense and all logic (the screenplay's conclusion isn't so much mysterious as woeful, inexplicable not in the sense that some great truths are carefully hidden within but inexplicable because Soderbergh cannot actually explain what point he he has been trying to make in the preceding, achingly-long 92 minutes).More worrying than that though is the way Soderbergh yet again seems incapable of improving upon an original: ?The Limey' wasn't merely one of the worst films of 1999, it was about as bad a remake as it's possible to achieve with source material as brilliant as ?Get Carter'. ..For older audiences, however, it's neither the Russian version nor anything by Resnais or Kubrick which is most likely to float clear of the subconscious at the conclusion of ?Solaris'. Rather, it's remembrance of sci-fi movie that scared the wits out of my generation of schoolkids -- the one in which the secrets of the mind came to knock at the doors of human existence.Forty-eight years on from the time it was made, Fred Wilcox's ?Forbidden Planet' still holds mesmeric sway: it had a tale to tell, and it knew exactly how to tell it. Would that ?Solaris' was worthy of a similar verdict.Rating: 7/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Soderburgh's Intimacy Takes Over, Lem/ Tarkovsky's Existential Examination Fades Away</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Thanks to Steven Soderbergh's audacious attempt to make an updated version of Andrei Tarkovsky's profound but dated sci-fi classic, the contemporary spectators can easily take a look at the Polish author Stanislaw Lem's planet Solaris, which communicates with the Earthlings via physically presented human figures who appear in a space station. However, Soderbergh's signature intimacy takes over in the film; while the confusing nonlinear sequence towards the end allows the audience many different interpretations, the sensuous last scene may leave the viewers a feeling that the film's argument is romance, rather than the existential examination of Lem and Tarkovsky.Aside from Lem/ Tarkovsky, as one independent piece, the film showcases the excellence of Soderbergh's one and only intimate atmosphere, distilled by great acting from the great casts (especially George Clooney and Jeremy Davies), simple and subtle art directions for the space station and the space landscape, and quiet and pop computer compositions that are reminiscent of Terry Riley and Carl Stone.</fullReview>

The problem is the nauseating dullness of the film - there was an opportunity here to really mix these elements and contrive something original, exciting, gripping, thought provoking and dramatic, and yet the direction turns it into a slow, ponderous love affair with itself.The dialogue is also a problem as it is so uninteresting - half way through the proceedings and we just don't care what is going on.Confusing flashbacks (Or are they), baffling camera movements and a general lack of clarity serve to frustrate rather than entertain.The performances are merely staple, with only Clooney being decent. 		<username>shoddy</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Slick, sparse, psychological sci-fi</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Solaris' does get lots of things right. It faithfully recreates the cold, lonely, brooding atmosphere of the remote space station, rendered in cold colours, bare metal and harsh, industrial background noise. The characters are well played with what little dialogue there is. The soundtrack is subtle and complements the feel of the film. The alien planet is beautifully rendered, in fact it's visually the most colourful and complex thing in the whole film, with pulsating colours and strange, wispy cloud formations.The reason 'Solaris' probably invokes such strong reactions is that it doesn't insult the intelligence with explanations, but leaves the viewer to fill in the gaps, of which there are plenty.My main criticism of it (as a 'mainstream art-house' film) is that it is possibly a little too slick. Everything about it is visually perfect, from the planet itself to the gratuitous, crowd-pleasing Clooney butt sequence. I would prefer to have seen a little 'Alien' style grubbiness, given the dysfunction of all the film's characters. This is scant criticism for such an ambitious project and I think Soderbergh has struck a happy medium between philosophical musing and a good old-fashioned love storyI also found that the sparseness of the film doesn't leave much to be savoured on subsequent viewings.Open your mind. 6/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Solaris (2002) vs. Solyaris (1972)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Why bring up this argument, you may ask?I was scamming through imdb.com and a quote, that is in my subject field (by Steven Soderbergh, director), is presented in the trivia for Solaris (2002)..I had an ENORMOUS problem with the remake, that refers to the said comment.Here is goes:I like Steven Soderbergh's films. I find his work lively and fresh, and also respect that he can adjust his aesthetics/style toward the films he makes. Most of his films vary wildly in content as well; also from commercial to artistic-like. Most of the films in his lap (Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989), Schizopolis (1996), Limey, The (1999), Erin Brockovich (2000), Traffic (2000), Ocean's Eleven (2001)) have one numerous awards and accolades and are even considered modern masterpieces in certain circles.Considered the most famous Soviet filmmaker since Sergei M. Eisenstein, Andrei Tarkovsky (on the other hand), was proven as one of the most idiosyncratic director's even now, after his tragic death. Despite his films being considered a part of world cinema's history (and being a big influence to some directors, note: Soderbergh), they fail to reach critic and commercial success. This is largely due to the same idiosyncrasies mention previously, they include affecting-yet-deliberate (Most Northern Americans read: slow) storytelling, blatant religious references (even as far as making them a part of the story and sometimes the story itself: The Mirror (1975), a biography of Tarkovsky) and ideas, Classical scoring and use of Classical Paintings within the films themselves, and last but not least: strong character development/psychology with references to each scene.Solyaris (1972) had every bit of Tarkovsky's vision of film making down to a science (easy argument; all of his films are highly respect, if not appreciated), no pun. Due to his highly eclectic form of storytelling and aesthetics; the atmosphere within the film is so dense and rich it begs for repeated viewings on that alone. Space is dirty. It is not a safe place to be, and not everyone is beautiful that goes there. Also, there is much more than a love story that is brewing in this film and it allows you to follow that major plot's course to the fullest (with 165 minutes running time). This is where I believe that Solaris (2002) suffers most (a meager 99 minutes running time).Solaris (2002) attempts to find middle ground with mainstream culture by eliminating subtleties and pushing the story into a faster momentum. Director James Cameron (of Titanic (1997) fame) was set to direct, but was said to have opted for a Producer credit instead, because he felt he couldn't portray the story completely. It's possible that even after James Cameron sidestepped, it still hurt the film, but I doubt it.This was Soderbergh's first attempt at melding art film with mainstream; it is evident even during Pre-Production (I began following the film, when he received the green light). It rode on a form of endeavor, but ultimately failed for it's lack of follow-through and inspiration. We needed more conflict and more underpinned suggestions for it to ride, but he wanted the mainstream to watch it. This is all shown through the perspective fades from George Clooney's character and Solaris itself, it's bland and adds very little or sometimes nothing to either the story or his psychology. Sadly it even becomes annoying. Solyaris (1972) includes similar transitions, but they play very differently.All of this to say that Solaris (2002) is a movie I shouldn't watch? Not exactly.It is a movie that disrespected the original film. And, after watching it I got to thinking that this movie was going to make everyone that watched it, not care to even check up on a great film that is: Solyaris (1972)Oh yea, and I believe that the quote mentioned above was cut-off, it should read: If the audience does not enjoy the first 10 minutes of the film, then they might as well leave and go watch the better version.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Solaris is a beauty to watch, and holds your attention with its apprehensive tone. Starting as a sci fi movie and crossing over into horror before submitting itself to a love story, Solaris uses multiple genres as tools for creating an overall emotional response to the storyline.Attempts to easily define this film will lead to frustration and possible irritation with the film itself- Comparisons to '2001' are unfair: "2001" was resolved with sheer sci-fi wonder - that took place in an almost inhumanly cold and detached narrative. "Solaris" is the sum of such wonder coupled with a love story, and a deeply internal treatise on some difficult to answer questions. Some have accused it of being slow, and despite the repeated use of slow, still shots of the stillness of the space station, the film is only an hour and a half, and solves its first mystery in 20 minutes.This answer to the question, "What's going on at Solaris?" only provokes mutliple new questions, some of which are unravelled by the movie's end. Even if as a viewer you don't hang on every shot you'll be more than occupied thinking about the significance of the ideas presented, and providing answers where there simply aren't any. Repeated viewings rewarded. I usually don't dig films like this. Ebert's review is dead on.</fullReview>

		<username>Jacob Rosen (bix171@comcast.net)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>An Experiment</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Steven Soderbergh's Americanized remake of Andrei Tarkovsky's Soviet 1972 science-fiction/philosophical space opera is a bold project, given that the material he's adopting--taken from the novel by Stanislaw Lem but directly inspired by Tarkovsky--is subdued and grim, with plenty of inertia (even though more than an hour of the tedious original is lopped off). Here, Soderbergh departs from the source material and wisely concentrates on the relationships between his characters rather than the philosophical concerns that grounded Tarkovsky's film. But the material remains perhaps too daunting for modern audiences, with George Clooney (rapidly becoming one of our most introspective actors) as a psychiatrist who travels to a space station surrounding a mysterious planet that sends emissaries representing the troubled pasts of the station's inhabitants; in Clooney's case, it's the apparition of his suicide wife (Natascha McElhone) that rekindles his dormant but conflicted emotions. Although it's clearly a personal film for Soderbergh about the ephemeral nature of interaction, it's unfortunately not compelling enough to be little more than another experimental challenge for him (as studied and careful as `Full Frontal' was spontaneous and indulgent), albeit a beautifully shot one (filmed, as usual, by the director under the pseudonym Peter Andrews; he also edited the film as Mary Ann Bernard) with a production design by Philip Messina that pays subtle homage to Tarkovsky's original.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-04-03</date>
		<username>citizenchris</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>a review</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A criticism of the film `Solaris' (2002) By Christopher Manning 8-3-03Ahh Science Fiction, that most marvelous of film genre. It can be used as a vehicle to the wonderful or the terrifying. It can take you to distant uncharted planets or a nightmarish future. On the surface `Solaris' appears to be about the former. Chris Kelvin is solicited by his friend to journey to the space station that is studying the titular planet. His visit will be the last attempt to solve the rather ambiguous problems plaguing the station. We soon discover that this film is much more than a space journey filled your typical sci-fi raz-taz. It's no less a journey to the very nature of how we as humans relate and perceive one another. When one considers the apparent hero of the films profession is that of a psychiatrist as apposed to say a cop or soldier. This alone should tell the audience that this film is certainly not run of the mill. `Solaris' is most certainly an exercise in minimalism. A style that perfectly suits the films subject matter. The audience is not spoon-fed a bunch of pretentious psychobabble. The story is told with raw images and raw emotions. It is both a departure from the majority of science fiction cinema and a return to what the genre is capable of.The films mages are eloquently photographed using a combination of static and handheld camera. A beautiful color palette is used to communicate to the audience where they are in the time line. Cool greys and blacks for the Solaris station. Warm earth tones for the terrestrial flashbacks. The emotions are that of a man who has lost his wife to suicide. He is then confronted with her apparent resurrection. This being the afore mentioned problem that was troubling the resident scientists of the station. It seems that every crewmember has their own `visitor'. The origin and purpose of which is unknown. Chris has to deal with facing a woman who looks and (almost) acts exactly like his deceased wife. On the surface it would appear he is being dealt a second chance. But he and his facsimile wife soon discover that this chance is fleeting when her true nature comes to the surface. The performances are superb all around. Mr. Clooney as Chris is called upon to display a wide range of emotions. He dose so with a subtle elegance that matches the rest of the films mood. All of the supporting roles are played nicely as well. Jeremy Davies disjointed and appropriately odd ball character plays as a good harbinger to things to come. Ultimately the overall experience of `Solaris' is a satisfying one. I havnt any real complaints about the film. It in every way represents what I love about not only a good sci-fi movie, but good movies in general. I feel the film demands a patient audience, but the reward is worth the wait.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Drying paint</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The only real undeniable quality of the original Tarkovsky film of SOLARIS is that is it SO impenetrable and pensive and "felt" that you couldn't say much about it aside from whether you liked it or didn't -- it's not something to be understood, but appreciated for what it is or not.Why, then, did Steven Soderbergh -- an exceptional director -- decide that he could remake it, remove the long, contemplative, meaningless MASS that was Tarkovsky and by trimming it down by an hour make it better? It is not a situation where the original was too good to be remade; rather, it is that to the extent the original worked at all was a miracle, and lightning had no way to strike twice. Soderbergh has nothing to add, no meaning to impose or new kinds of style to perk it up. He's merely taken one boring, pointless movie and made a shorter boring, pointless movie from its dropping. There are no revelations that fill in the blanks, no explanations of character or plot, or even any good action or sex to supercharge it. This SOLARIS is stolen style without substance -- or, what substance there is, just as impossible to find. It is anti-cinema of the worst kind, with lifeless performances and heavy emotions, all floating as rootless as a tree in a cyclone. Keep your head down, you don't want to get beaned by it.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Ocean's Twelve it ain't...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film has divided audiences, even in my own household; I thought it was really good, and my wife hated it and thought it was the most boring film she'd ever seen. So fired up was she that she ranted and raved incessantly for about an hour after we came out of the cinema. So what is the film at the centre of this debate? Well, it's is Steven Soderburgh's latest collaboration with George Clooney: a slow, meditative piece of filmmaking based on the seventies Russian sf classic Solyaris.The story involves Chris Kelvin (Clooney), a grieving psychiatrist, being called on to visit a space station orbiting a strange pink and blue planet (that looks remarkably like a human brain), where strange things have been happening to those on board. The planet is causing memories of the crew to become real living things, hence the strange behaviour and refusal of the crew to leave.When Kelvin arrives he is forced to confront his own feelings about his wife's suicide when he is given another chance to be with her. The story here is really secondary to the existential questions the movie poses, and the atmosphere and emotion that it tries to portray. I feel that for the most part the movie succeeds. It is certainly a brave experiment for Soderburgh and Clooney (last seen together with Oceans Eleven), and unfortunately has not been a great commercial success in the States (partly due to bad marketing). I fear that it will suffer the same fate here in the UK, where we want our Hollywood product loud, fast and manipulative. I think it may do well in Europe though, as it is more akin to the French style of filmmaking, where more stress is on dialogue and philosophy than on all out action.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>All in his head</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***Spoiler Alert***** I too got pulled into this film and ended up watching it a few times (once with commentary). I found it more interesting the more I thought about it. My view on it is probably a bit different and more symbolic than most and not necessarily what was intended. I see the whole story as Chris Kelvin's grieving process over his wife's death. That everything that goes on in the film can be seen as his going further into his own mind/memory/perceptions to heal from it; to try to come to peace with the memory of her. The planet Solaris even resembled images of electrical activity in the brain - neurons firing. The further he goes on his journey, the more dynamic, intense and closer Solaris gets. The various characters could even be viewed as aspects of himself. Gordon - the ego/defensive/protective side that wants to avoid pain, change; the part that wants to be rid of Rheya's memory altogether; the survival instincts that want to get back to regular life (earth). Snow - the intellect - pure thought, but we see only a "replica" of what his intellect was since Rheya's death - the replica is disjointed, fragmented, way "out there," seeming like it should make sense but too vague to be clear. Gibarian - the charming, outgoing, social - possible husband/father - side who becomes lost after Rheya's death - thus Chris being deadened/robotic in his dealings with the world since. Trying to find &amp; help the "Gibarian" aspect of himself is what sets him on the whole journey. He ends up having to review his whole history with Rheya - all his "film clip" memories of their past. He has to relive it all and let himself feel (the pain &amp; pleasure) in order to move through it. Only by fully surrendering and connecting to his child-like self (symbolized by Gibarian's son), no expectations /open to what is to come/innocence is he finally able to come to a place of forgiveness. Forgiveness of both himself &amp; Rheya so he can be at peace with her memory and connect back to himself.</fullReview>

		<username>Dan Franzen (dfranzen70)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Thoughtful and thought-provoking sci-fi</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Based on the novel by Stanislaw Lem, this cerebral sci-fi yarn has psychologist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) being sent to investigate strange happenings on a remote space station orbiting an odd planet. Kelvin has ghosts of his own to deal with, as he is haunted by memories of his wife, a suicide victim. His mission is to find out why the crew members have not come home and to explain their bizarre behavior (as evidenced by their plaintive messages imploring Kelvin to visit).There have been many movies that depict what happens when strange happenings are investigated, and as in most of those movies, nothing here is really as it seems. The tone for the tension and suspense is set almost immediately, as Kelvin awakes onboard the station next to his dead wife!Who is she? What is she? Is she really his wife, returned from the grave? What affect does Solaris the planet have on this.... this entitity? Is Kelvin turning as nutty as the remaining crew members? Is he hallucinating his wife? Is he even on the space station - is this a bad dream?Devoid of outlandish special effects and with a threadbare cast, the movie must lean on the solemn plot and the stoic acting of Clooney. This is his show all the way - his is the flawed hero and the willing victim combined into one multilayered character. It's some of Clooney's best work; he cannot rely on his whiplash smile or suave charm. Neither of those qualities, although surely valuable in other films, can help his character here.Like the best thinking-man's sci-fi, Solaris doesn't answer every question. It's mystical without being too abstract, and its quiet strength lies in what one doesn't see.The only drawback is that it's often tough to understand the actions of the crew members, including Kelvin. Are they insane, or merely acting? Hamlet himself may not have been able to discern the truth here. Compounding this is the sometimes unlikeability of Kelvin himself. It would be taking the easy way out, however, to have made him into some sort of superhero. Therefore even though it's tough at times to relate to Kelvin and consequently to root for him to succeed, this is a successful, well-made film, thanks to its complexities and multilayered main character.</fullReview>
	</review>

I fear Clooney's star-power or the fact that James Cameron produced the picture may have prevented the film from being released to a more suitable audience. Lewis called "true science fiction", in that the science of the situation is necessary for the sequence of events to occur. There is no way for Chris to re-live his past mistakes with Rheya unless she shows up for him to interact with her.Another problem most viewers may find with the film is that it is character driven. This is difficult for many American audiences to take (coming from a goal-oriented society) and few have the patience or constitution to try and find out more about a character. Plots are much easier to digest.It's a beautiful film, well photographed and stunningly directed. The performances are strong, but handle what would have been a difficult script for lesser actors. The sets are breath taking and the costuming is detailed without being ridiculous.I'm only sorry it was set before the wrong audience. Their disappointment in this film is based on ignorance and an assumption that all science fiction belongs in the "action" or "horror" sections of their local Blockbuster.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-09-23</date>
		<username>sackleywhistle (bthighton@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A genuine surprise</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Very different in feel to Tarkovsky's original, this is, by Soderbergh's admission, one third the original, one third the novel (by Stanislaw Lem) and one third Soderbergh's own imagination. Its also somewhat of a departure for all involved, particularly Clooney and Soderbergh, though bearing the fingerprints of his style.It must be said that this is not the film that the terrible marketing campaign offered - it is not a funky space-set romance, though it does take place in space and is a romantic story. It is however, a very slow, deliberate film. Only essential information is given and, going from a 61-page script to a 90-minute film, there is little dialogue but a lot of detail. Many will find it too slow and possibly boring. But there is so much here to appreciate. It is a film of mood and feelings, creating a beautiful and emotional atmosphere, in which events unwind gradually, rather than an intense plot-driven mish-mash of ideas.Soderbergh's intention is to question the very nature of existence and of love - if you knew something wasn't real, would you avoid getting attached to it, even if it was the one thing you always wanted, more than anything? If it meant never seeing home again, but spending forever in a tiny space with just that person, would rationality cease to exist? Do we only need that one thing that we crave to survive? Beyond this, there are semi-religious overtones added as well - is Solaris heaven? A place where all wishes are granted at the cost of "human" life?The aspect that stands out first and foremost the acting. Viola Davis is wonderful, Jeremy Davies is never less than interesting, but Clooney and Natasha McElhone have never been this good. Expanding his range even more after Out of Sight and O Brother Where Art Thou?, Clooney reaches depth you wouldn't have expected of such a matinee-style star. His Chris Kelvin is sad, intense, smart and realistic - the scene where Clooney wakes up to see his dead wife is a wonderful moment of acting, watching him try to bring himself round and shake off the image, only to realise its real. And McElhone is perfectly cast and surprising as the other half of the emotional core. Having been efficient in Ronin and The Truman Show, she seems to have acquired untapped gravitas and beauty in this film, looking absolutely beautiful in a very virginal, pure sense, belying the complexities and internal grief of her character. She too has many moments that just seem incredibly real, as if she forgot to act and just believed in what was happening. The cinematography and effects are very proficient without being showy, creating a believable environment within which the bizarre events are grounded in a reality not so unbelievable. Solaris itself is simply gorgeous to look at, conjuring up images of planets and cells at the same time, hinting at a universality which is not one thing nor the other, but all things which cannot be explained in one term, again suggesting a godliness to it. And the music is brilliantly subtle, flavouring the images to give it that atmosphere of longing and loss and also beauty, never suggesting what we should feel but rather what the on-screen characters are feeling.Soderbergh has made his most mature film here, eschewing the "cool" editing and camera tricks of films such as Traffic, Erin Brockovich, The Limey and Out of Sight for a more stately, sophisticated tone. It never feels forced or unbelievable and, while some of its twists are somewhat predictable, you dont feel cheated at all by the end, rather that everything played out as it should: dramatic and sad in places, beautiful in others, unsettling at times and ultimately quite profound. There really isn't anything wrong with this film, if you are in the mood to have a film wash over you and cause you to ruminate on the ideas of mortality, loss and redemption. Kudos to all involved for making something slightly different.</fullReview>
	</review>

I do believe that people who are more comfortable with concrete thoughts and actions will dislike it intensely (as shown by the incredible volume of negative user reviews here).If you read, and enjoy being gently lowered into a different world by a good author, then you will probably enjoy this movie thoroughly. Everything about it, from the beginning (no credits, it just starts) to the end, works to take you away from the norm and move you towards Solaris and its own reality.I saw the original film a few months before the new version was released. Although I respected it for the vision and style, I was not able to really feel a part of it. Maybe because of the subtitles, or because its pace is more designed for a European sensibility, I found myself drifting away from it many times. Clooney's Solaris, with its quiet feeling also allows me to drift, but pulls me in and holds me there.When a movie or book is able to envelop me in its dream, and actually hold me there long after the end, it has accomplished its goal. Solaris held its pull on me long after the last view of the planet disappeared from my screen. I was left with that dreamlike feeling and mood for a long time afterwards. To me, that is the ultimate sign of an excellent story well directed and acted.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-09-15</date>
		<username>JR</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A thoughtful sci-fi movie, creepy, but without horror (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Solaris is a strange, beautiful world, remote from Earth, which is being investigated by a survey team to assess its economic potential. However abnormal occurrances have plagued the team including the suicide of the team leader and the appearance to the crew of persons from their past experience, who cannot possibly be physically present (some are known to be dead) in the survey ship.Enter psychologist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney), charged with dispeling the problems/"hallucinations", only to be beset by them himself in overwhelming measure when his dead wife appears, not once but twice (the first he ejects from the ship in an escape pod).The presence of physicist and hard rationalist Gordon (Viola Davis) does much to prevent the crew (and plot) from disintegrating into a babble of mumbo-jumbo mysticism. There are no detectable psychotropic agents which could be causing the crew to imagine these occurances. The beings rather, are constructs from the memories of the persons who knew them, created somehow by Solaris itself. As such, they are what the person who knew them thinks they were, rather than the original person. But very real enough. They exhibit an almost indestructibility (if injured or killed, they shortly self-resurrect), though Gordon develops a method of dispelling them using exotic radiation.While all understand with their minds that the appearance of these beings is undesirable ("What if this was to spread to Earth" screams Gordon), emotion overwhelms reason and Kelvin is determined to hold onto this remnant of his wife, however imperfect. There are tense moments between Gordon and Kelvin.The ending is anti-climactic and enigmatic. It is Gordon who makes the decision to return to Earth carrying the rest of the crew with her (they seem incapable of any making any significant decisions). The crew don't fall into a senseless slaughter of each other, nor do the beings suddenly turn hostile. In the deja vu sequence near the film's very end, Kelvin finds himself on Earth and cuts himself (again) while preparing a meal. While attending to the wound, he is arrested by the sudden appearance of his wife. He asks, "Am I alive... or dead?" She assures "We don't have to think like that anymore. We're together now. Everything we've done is forgiven. Everything." They fall into a long, clinging embrace which dissolves into the image of Solaris, now very reminicient of an embryo.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-08-29</date>
		<username>JasonJayDelmonico</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>If you looked up "Pretentious" in the dictionary...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Final Score: 3.7 (out of 10)One could easily imagine how if the Oscar winning director of `Titanic' and the Oscar winning director of `Traffic' got together they could have proven to be a force so unstoppable no studio would dare get in their way. Which is a great thing. Yet, what writer/director Stephen Soderbergh and producer James Cameron choose to collaborate on was `Solaris' ? a pure-cinema novelty movie that wants to ask the greater questions in life but never gets around to it amid all of Soderbergh's pretentious showboating and visual handstands. We first meet George Clooney's Kelvin (cute, ain't it), living on Earth, in a series of static cut scenes, speaking out of context dialogue and often in mid-sentence. He is summoned up into space after all the action has taken place to solve the mystery of what Solaris. The movie proceeds relatively quiet with minimal dialogue and an emphasis on atmosphere and visually stylized close-ups then on any action or exploring it's ideas. I'm not complaining yet. The movie is elevated from the trash heap by it's occasional visual wonder (Soderbergh gets the most out of close-ups) and terrific performances from Clooney and Natascha McElhone (who must have the biggest, most expressive eyes in the business) . Jeremy Davies' take on Snow proves to create, by far, the most interesting character in the movie.Soderbergh is doing his Stanley Kubrick impression with ?Solaris'. He keeps the movie as open-ended, as irritating and looking as 70s as possible. He recreates the style immaculately but lacks the razor sharp touch to weave the substantive ideas through it. In vintage Kubrick fashion the music is as mixed a bag as it comes ? sometimes the pinging orchestrations are perfectly moody and sometimes it sounds like sound check tests or feels like the symptom of a fever. However, unlike Kubrick (and Tarkovsky's film), `Solaris' is ultimately not worth putting up with the director's pretentious pure-cinema indulgences. Kubrick could be annoy, but also brilliant and 'Solaris' is far from brilliant in any part. It's not that it's a remake, or what Tim Burton might call a 'reimagining', that is the problem, for Soderbergh and Cameron approach this material with the gusto as if it's never been done before. It's just that in the decades since Stanislaw Lem's book and the Tarkovsky film this premise and the supposed deep philosophizing in the film has been run into the ground. Michael Crichton's fascinating novel ?Sphere' explored the themes with more depth and creativity. But when Barry Levinson's disastrously botched adaptation of that book came out in 1998 it was rightly called on the carpet for it's ?Star Trek' level approach to the premise. Here we have a similar situation. Soderbergh is so caught up in being ambiguous, in making a true art-house science fiction film, that the movie never gets around to being aware of it's own concepts. It throws in conversations here and there ? one involving atheist Kelvin debating the ridiculousness of man's personification of God ? but they are more like flailing red herrings then pieces of a constructible puzzle. To say that this ?Solaris' is intelligent and through provoking and profound is to say that any movie that deals in the issues of God, death, the essence of being human and the like is just automatically just as profound - whether or not it actually says anything new or is just surface level pontificating. I certainly didn't want everything spelled out, I just wanted a little more substance, a little more exploration of it's premise insinuated. All of this nothingness, literally dragged out into what has to be the longest 90 minutes ever put to film. This is a filmmaker's movie from beginning to end, in which Soderbergh seems more concerned with amusing himself then giving the audience anything to take away. Ultimately forgettable.</fullReview>
	</review>

It can be confusing, but for anyone who has been in a relationship with someone who is a little unstable this movie will be heartbreaking. Too bad some people don't get it. 		<username>dromasca</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Where Real Science Fiction Meets Hollywood</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In one of the special features documentaries coming with the DVD, director Soderbergh explains his 'Solaris', as a science fiction work 'as it used to be': less about robot fights and laser guns, more about humans. He is correct, with one observation - Real science fiction always was, is, and will be about human beings and their emotions - fear, hope, love. It is Hollywood who hijacked the genre and transformed it in a commercial pop-art based mainly on effects, at the expense of what real art is meant to be. But not all cinema is done at Hollywood, thanks God, and directors like Soderbergh find ways to do good films even in the Hollywood system.For example, this 'Solaris' is a legitimate attempt to reconcile the two approaches. It takes the classic 'Solaris' book (by Stanislaw Lem) and picture (a real masterpiece by Tarkowski) and gives it a Hollywood twist - the story is more about relationship and human emotion, less about the experience to discover a new civilisation and world, with different rules than ours. This works no bad, and 'Solaris' is a good film. The robot fights and laser guns fans will be disappointed, but they have many other films to satisfy their lust.Compared with the classical film of Tarkowski this 'Solaris' loses in depth - but it is probably on purpose. Staging and camera are good, though reminding too much of Kubrick's '2001'. Casting is interesting - most of the characters including George Clooney seem slightly mis-casted, but it somehow helps, adding to the strange atmosphere of the film. Clooney always seems to act better than you would expect, and I wonder why. It may be his looks that are too close to the 50's legends (Carry Grant, James Stewart). But then, as in 'Brother' he surprises the audiences for the good. I kind of dis-liked the final. It tried to be at the same time original and happy-end-ish, but it looked confusing and cheap to me. However, there was a lot of good stuff in the rest of the film to make it worth watching. 8/10 on my personal scale.</fullReview>

I would not call it my favorite movie but I would recommend it to someone who might like something besides action/adventure movies.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-07-31</date>
		<username>Kennuff</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An entrancing, intelligent, ethereal beauty.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Solaris" is one of the best films of 2002. Soderbergh and his incredible team should be commended for creating such a splendid, miraculously crafted triumph of modern sci-fi cinema. This is science fiction with class, style, and atmosphere. If you are not appreciative of slow cameras and dialogue, do not see this movie. Now, for people with taste, let me tell you what you are in for: a thoroughly enjoyable emotional space opus designed for adult-minded people with a sense of wonder to spare. George Clooney is a psychologist sent to a remote planet's space station to investigate the strange occurrences affecting the crew. Steven Soderbergh continues to dazzle with his eclectic palette of films, and is quickly on his way to becoming a legendary director. George Clooney proves he can really act in this one, with bouts of emotions rarely seen in his usually pretty-boy demeanor. Natascha McElhone shines as the wife. The supporting cast includes Jeremy Davies, Ulrich Tukur, and Viola Davis, all of whom provide exceptional dramatic support. The sets, costumes, ships and the planet itself are wonders to behold. This film is an unforgettable experience. Nothing like it has been made since "2001: A Space Odyssey". The film is serious, odd, haunting, and bold. You should consider yourself blessed to see a film this delicate in today's world of cinematic drivel. Thank you Steven Soderbergh! 10/10</fullReview>
	</review>

Juxtapose Kelvin's reaction at his wife's abortion, and later, shooting wife copy no. 1 into space. The message being your morality can and will change, depending on your circumstances. I also like that Kelvin is human--and not one dimensional. Its refreshing actually to see a bit of weakness in a "hero". I think that whole 'don't tell copy no. 1' stuff is hilarious.I liked the Kubrick-ey space shots--what else can you do? I'll think of them as 'tributes'--of course, the space station was the best and most realistic ever. The soundtrack was good.I like that there are questions unanswered. Like the 'formula' isn't that dead people from your past come back to life--cause Snow makes a copy of himself...we don't know what Gordon's visitor is, and doesn't Gibarian's son exist on earth? Kelvin copies himself--so maybe he was a copy already when he got there? Who knows?I always like sublety and get annoyed when I am hit on the head with the 'answers'.So for me I took away alot from the movie--the who are we and what are we doing here anyway theme. 		<username>Franck</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>"I see dead people from outer space... Are they real?"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film had me really upset.I generally like Soderbergh's movies, especially his daring ones. So I was expecting something outstanding.He sadly missed in this movie every single opportunity to give the potentially moving story a chance to touch the viewer. To be moved by this, one has to be so sensitive that he/she cries when viewing "Dallas".Yeah, the spaceships look good. Yeah, the cinematoraphy is neat. Yeah, the woman has touching eyes (the "Emily Watson effect"). Yeah, Clooney has a nice butt. So what? This is just another of this modern and uninteresting movies which, instead of using cinematic narratives, just **illustrates**, "nicely" and "cleverly", a story like if we already knew it before... and expects from the viewer to be immersed in the story just because it's a good story. Bad news, Steven, a director's work is not only showing what he can do, using creative editing and cool cinematography... He actually has a role to play in the way the viewer relates to the story and the characters! Have you forgotten this since "Sex, lies and videos"?We know nothing about the characters, and we are asked just to deal with what happens, and the way they behave. I don't mind to feel far from the characters if a philosophical purpose is cleverly exposed or evocated, or if the audiovisual narratives incline to meditation, like in 2001. Here it's almost impossible, as the whole movie is drawned deep into a stubborn musical score that makes each scene "feel" exactly like the one before. This music seems to tell you: "nothing is happening, don't worry, you shall not be moved, or scared, or even interested, just be patient and the film will eventually come to an end"... Zzzzzzz** - the only meditation allowed is to think of the shopping list... result: people who already don't like that much slow-paced movies will HATE them after seeing Solaris. Well done, indeed, Steve, well done!There is no real emotional drive in Solaris, though the director seems to think differently. Good for him. To feel concerned by a character's emotions, one must get close to him/her. The flashbacks in Solaris are an inadequate way to fill the gaps of the early narrative, and they give only flat explanations, not meaningful inner motives. A touching love story is not made out of mere facts, neither is a good SF story.The whole thing looks pretentious and utterly empty, far too clean, intellectual and desincarnate, and the many nods to 2001 only make me think that Kubrick seems to have really traumatized directors, even talented ones like De Palma or Soderbergh, who have both been completely unable to come up with a "space opera" of their own without basically mimicking Kubrick's work, and fall into every obvious trap that lead to make boring SF movies "in the manner of 2001".When will a talented, artistic director have the guts to make a really creative, independant and meaningful new movie about the meeting of man with a cosmic intelligence, without desperatly trying to compete with 2001? Is there such a lack of imagination and creativity in the movie industry?Solaris was, for me, as interesting as a mix bewteen the worse aspects of "Star Trek", "Sixth sense" and "A.I.". How does it sound? Not very good. "I see dead people from outer space... 		<username>Glober</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>For those who see "meaning" in the absence of any.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Some films take a compelling concept, and create a story that is moving, poignant, meaningful and thought-provoking. Other films are unabashed entertainment to thrill the masses. And then there are films like SOLARIS. Films made for only one reason: to satisfy the egos of filmmakers who actually think they're saying something.It has become its own genre.This last kind of film has a small but earnest following. And you can bet their audience will find meaning in ANY tale. But you can also bet they'll never agree with each other on what that meaning IS. Oh, but that's the point, you see. It's "interpretive". It's subjective. We all see different meanings in it. That's the whole beauty of it, they say.A similar kind of film is David Lynch's MULHOLLAND DRIVE. And it would seem that people will tend to like or dislike both. And if you come across someone who LIKES it, don't dare suggest it's awful -- or else it's assumed you're not intelligent enough to "get it". (Or perhaps just not creative enough to have imposed your own meaning upon it -- which, let's face it, if I wanted to WRITE the movie, I wouldn't have come to see YOURS!)Personally, I prefer a story. I prefer something that makes sense and has a forward motion. Something that adds up -- ALL of it. I can go cerebral and make the challenging mental connections along with the best of them. But SOLARIS and its breed (and their followers) believe that juxtaposing images in a random or lingering fashion -- as long as you have a thread of a story -- makes for some sort of artistic masterpiece.But it doesn't.There are some very nice elements in SOLARIS. The concept, for one. I haven't seen the original nor read the book (which shouldn't be required when seeing a film, by the way). But the story concept is EXCELLENT. I would have LOVED a well-told version of this thing.Jeremy Davies also gives a dynamic performance (hammy, perhaps, but at least it was fascinating to watch). Clooney was solid. McElhone was radiant. Davis was good. I enjoyed the score and the aesthetically-pleasing cinematography and the expansive set.But when Soderbergh is at the helm of a story that DOESN'T have a clear linear drive (as BROCKOVICH and OCEAN'S both did), you get self-indulgent filmmaking, pure and simple. TRAFFIC's another example. Great to look at, excellent acting, nice scenes -- adds up to nothing we hadn't seen on a hundred television shows. Maybe it's just me, but I find Soderbergh the most consistently overrated director working today (well, alongside Lynch, perhaps).The worst part is that I LOVED the IDEAS behind these films. I would've liked each of those mentioned here to have been great WITHOUT having ME supply their meanings. I just wish the filmmakers had done their jobs (tell a story), rather than pander to those few who find meaning where there is none.If that's you, then this is your film.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Middling Existential Experiment</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A most amazing thing occurred when I sat down in my theater to watch Steven Soderbergh's sci-fi remake, 'Solaris'. The majority of the theater was women, no small part I'm sure to George Clooney and the promise to see his posterior not once, but twice. As the film progressed I kept hearing the rattling of seats and the exit doors. When the lights came back on more than half my theater had walked out on 'Solaris'. I have never seen this many walk outs for any film before, and if one has to hold this title 'Solaris' certainly does not deserve this dubious honor.Clooney plays Chris Kelvin, super future psychologist who is struggling to overcome the grief over the suicide of his wife, Rheya (Natascha McElhone). Clooney is dispatched to a space station orbiting the mysterious glowing planet Solaris. Seems strange goings on, are, well, going on. When he arrives he finds that the station head has taken his own life and the two remaining crewmembers on board could use more than a few hugs.Clooney goes to sleep (in a bed resembling bubble-wrap) and is startled awake when his dead wife is suddenly lying right beside him. But is it his wife? Is it merely his memories being recounted? Is it Solaris messing with his gray matter? Does Rheya have consciousness of the past or of her self? What are her thoughts on her new materialization? Good luck Steven Soderbergh, existentialist party of one.It's not that 'Solaris' is necessarily a bad film, it's just that it's plodding, mechanical and overly ambitious. There are long periods of staring, followed by brief exposition, then more staring, sometimes earnestly but mostly slack-jawed. 'Solaris' is attempting to be an existential meditation on identity and self, but what really occurs is a lot of nothingness. For a movie that was over three hours in its original 1971 Russian conception, and a mere 93 minutes in its slimmer Soderbergh size, I could likely get this movie done in 6 minutes. It could be argued that its arduous pacing amplifies its methodical subject matter, but whatever.Clooney has said in interviews how Solaris was the most challenging role of his career. To this I make a collective psssha noise of disagreement. Clooney turns from grief-stricken to confusion, then back to grief-stricken with nary a line of dialogue. The effect is more dampening than emotional.I'm very pleased to see the glassy-eyed, apple-cheeked beauty McElhone in movies again. She seemed to be on the cusp of mainstream acceptance after prominent roles in 1998's 'Truman Show' and 'Ronin', yet she just disappeared. McElhone is a wonderfully expressive actress and deserves to be a leading lady.Soderbergh's take on existential dread could be described as a noble failure. 'Solaris' is the type of overreaching, underachieving film only really talented people could make. And for anyone wanting to leave after the double dose of Clooney's derriere, they both happen in the first 30 minutes. You can go after that.C+</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>After 30 years, Hollywood has yet to learn from Tarkovsky</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I congratulate producer James Cameron and Steven Soderberg for deciding to film Stanislaw Lem's book. And yet...what a disaster Soderberg's Solaris turned out to be!!If you liked this film see Andrei Tarkovsky's film made 30 years ago when most moviegoers around the world thought Russians only made third rate propaganda war movies.Tarkovsky's film gripped you in so many ways that Soderberg cannot. Tarkovsky's choice of Bach's music "Chorale in F minor", his casting of the brilliant Estonian actor Yuri Jarvet (Grigori Kozintsev's choice of King Lear that had Lord Laurence Olivier doffing his cap) as Dr Snauth a character Soderberg tried to recreate ineffectively in Snow (Jeremy Davis), Tarkovsky's brilliant visuals (Soderberg does copy the rain on the windows)--give you sufficient reasons to realize that Andrei Tarkovsky remains one of the finest filmmakers of the century--a filmmaker who most moviegoers do not adequately know about in the US and elsewhere.What amused me is that before the film was released there were the publicity about how Soderberg wanted to make the film as one superior to Tarkovsky. Soderberg is no Tarkovsky and will never be.Tarkovsky did not use nudity to make his film sell--his film has made waves even when the Communists were afraid of Tarkovsky's messages and suppressed his work in the Seventies in many ways--all because of the care he took with the direction, the script, the editing, the photography and the music. His script, so different from that of the Soderberg film, delivered more punch without a Clooney and his fabulous voice. Hollywood's answer to Tarkovsky is probably the late Orson Welles and in recent times, Terrence Mallick. Cameron probably knew his limitations as a director and cleverly opted to produce the movie. Soderberg thought he was bigger than he is and attempted to remake Tarkovsky's work without even acknowledging the work of the Russian genius in the few press statements I came across.If the Soderberg film appeals to you, it is Stanislaw Lem that gets you not Soderberg. While the film is better than the average Hollywood product this film does not stand up to great cinema elsewhere in any department save for the above-average sound editing.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Exclusively for movie lovers</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"What if?". This is the question of Solaris. More specifically, "What if we could bring back our lost ones to our side?". That is the question flowing throughout Sodebergh's movie. I've never thought that I would watch a film based on a single rethorical question, but indeed, the nature of this question is what gives it the juice. And, indeed, the juices are flowing on this one. Made by an acclaimed director which is first of all a movie addict, this movie is Steven Soderbergh's gift to every people that shares with him a true passion for cinema. And nobody else. The general audience will hate it - slow paced, slow acted and slow all the way, the movie is almost like a play, tightfully enclosed in its capsule. But these few characters, these few situations are only an apparent face for an overwhelming reality - emotions are the sheer canvas of this picture. The story is so simple it reaches the most minimalistic heights in an american movie since Kubrick went into space - Dr. Chris Kelvin (Clooney) is sent to a space station near gas planet Solaris to investigate the strange occurences on it and to rescue the remainder of the crew. But when he arrives, it's clear that this is no simple bail-out mission and soon he will know that the reasons to return are far more difficult to find than the reasons to stay. The movie ends up being a strikingly lensed space drama, with the freshness of some choices (the fact that the movie has so few characters and only 93 minutes gives it a mood that is based on essence). And its simplicity is its greatest asset. Some would consider a remake of Tarkovski's work pure heresy. But Soderbergh suceeds in paying his respects, and accomplishes what every remake should be - a new insight into a known movie. A true tour de force, and a proof that when there is a will to stay out of the studio system and its sometimes corruptive formulae, there is also a way.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Complementary to Tarkovsky</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I liked this film a lot, it sent goose pimples all over my body most of the time, and I felt very relaxed after it. This is something very few film achieve. But some of them are by Andrey Tarkovsky, who filmed "Solyaris" in 1972. And I don't think I can tell right now which film is better. Sure: Tarkovsky is unique, his genius unsurpassed, probably a league of his own, while it is much easier to compare Soderbergh's work with that of others. But Soderbergh looked at Tarkovsky's "Solyaris" very attentively, with self-consciousness and respect. In his version, he stressed the points underdeveloped by Tarkovsky: emotional clarity, acting and closure in the screenplay (the latter not always to the best of the film). He wisely did not try to compete with Tarkovsky in fields in which he can't be beaten: visual poetry and philosophy. Tarkovsky's Kris is great, but so sullen you wonder what kind of psychologist he is to send into such an unclear situation. Clooney is much more convincing in this respect. In Soderbergh's version, people are also much less secretive about their view of the visitors and their emotions.SPOILERSI do not understand what people do not understand about the ending of the film. It's pretty clear: The visitors are part of Solaris, an alien intelligence. Chris stays on the station and makes contact with Solaris, embodied by the boy. The final scenes are not set on earth, but on an earth recreated from Chris memory by Solaris. He himself is not more than a memory - his original body has been destroyed during the fall of the station. Thus he overcomes the distinction between humans and visitors, and the one between real people and images. Draw from this any philosophical conclusion you want...</fullReview>

And the edited sequence of shots and scenes built just the right tension.A 9 out of 10! Really great, great cinema!</fullReview>

Indirecly the film addresses what it is to be human, the nature of memory, the possibility of life after death, and the question of what makes an individual. It does these things in a subtle way, letting the questions arise as the film develops. Answers are offered, but obliquely, perhaps more as suggestions.The film itself is, I think, well made. I thought the music was beautiful, and the performances understated but effective. I liked the fact that this was not a science fiction film, despite being set in space, the setting being paradoxically naturalistic ( as much as a man made structure can be ).If you're after an million mile an hour rampage through the galaxy with heroes, villains and a climax then you won't like this. If that's what you're expecting you'll be disappointed. If you would like to see a reflective film rich in ambiguity then you will come out feeling you have had a very satisfying evening.I haven't seen the original. As it's held to be a masterpiece I suspect it may surpass this version. Nevertheless I would be surprised if I see a more thoughtful film this year.PS If all you're interested in is George Clooney's bottom ( as many seem to focus on ) then you were definitely in the wrong theatre.</fullReview>

I sat and tried to work out what kind of a movie it was. Exciting? No way. Tense? Nope. Thrilling? Funny? Humourous? No. Emotional? Surprisingly, no. Interesting? No, sorry, not at all.Having watched plenty of other films (and TV series like Star Trek!) make the same kind of story much more engaging, I found I really didn't care what happened. They even tried a couple of twists, but these just came off as "let's-add-a-twist."I suppose the acting was okay given the limited material, but in the end the movie just seemed rather pointless, contrived, dull (which I may have mentioned already), and unbelievable. There was the promise of much, with exciting possibilities set up, but the promise wasn't delivered, unfortunately.(As a slight aside, it never looks good when people are sitting in the cinema with their eyes closed, and worse still when people walk out 15 minutes from the end; both of these happened when I saw Solaris.)</fullReview>

I have read various reviews and I'm slightly put off by the fact that no one else seems to have seen the film in a similar way that I did. The common theory I have heard is one similar to maybe 'The Matrix'. My theory (and please remember that I have not seen the original so can't compare in any way) is that Solaris was a kind of metaphor for the state of mind that a person enters after someone close to them dies. George Clooney, like anyone who loses someone close to them has a choice to make, move on and live without them, or refuse to be able to live in a world that doesn't include the person that you love. I think that the return of Natascha McElhone is symbolic for the way that people relive sections of their life before their loved one died, the fact that the way Clooney remembers McElhone effects her is true to the way people question their memories. The ending when Clooney has returned to earth and once again McElhone appears, I think shows that Clooney choose that he could not live without his wife and was willing to sacrifice his life in order to be with her forever.I would really love to hear any comments about what other people thought of 'Solaris' and whether or not anyone out there agrees with me in the slightest.Final note: See this film, it's gonna be huge!!!</fullReview>

		<username>BentPenguin (ovais_j@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fascinating</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Solaris" is not a film for someone looking for straight science fiction. Sodebergh goes back to his European roots to present a film that is slow, but (with a little perseverance) ultimately rewarding. The plot unfolds at a leisurely pace, the atmospherics are brilliant, the lighting (which surely deserves an award) keeps one peering at the screen. The plot elements are not particularly compelling - the philosophical elements are. However, the script examines the latter in not enough detail. The themes of death, mortality and memory intertwine themselves, but never really manage to work their way into the script. This results in a film that is visually stunning but one that fears to tread further into the philosophical debate it commences. Perhaps Sodebergh felt his script was too highbrow and didn't want to alienate the broader swathe of viewers he thought he may otherwise attract. The result is a film which is neither traditional science fiction nor High Art. Nevertheless, it remains one of the more intelligent films I've seen emerge from Hollywood for some time.</fullReview>
	</review>

I'm not convinced everyone in the future will wander around explaining all their technological marvels all the time like in some sf movies, and doing so just detracts from the storyline.
